Week 1 Summary

 

Learning Objective: By the end of this week, students will have demonstrated the following: How to use an IDE to create a JavaScript file, how to run JavaScript files with NodeJS, explain some common uses for JavaScript. 

 

Prior to Class During Class Following Class
  • Attend MAD&D Orientation.
  • Install and configure Bootcamp on their Macbook Pro.
 The learning activities for this week will include:
  • Lectures about programming concepts
  • Installation of NodeJS
  • Installation of Brackets IDE
  • Accessing CodeSchool.com
  • Setting up CodePen account
  • Learn about variables 
  • Running JavaScript programs
  • Read all the content from this week's module
  • Review all Tutorial material (video & text)
  • Read the Summary for next week
  • Complete Installs & Accounts
  • Complete JavaScript Road Trip Part 1 Level 1

    Installing Node.JS

    Node.js is a standalone JavaScript interpreter.

    At this point in the program, that sentence probably doesn't mean much to you. However, it is a tool that we will be using throughout the entire program for many different purposes. 

    JavaScript is one of the core programming languages that you will be learning.

    NodeJS is a program that you can run in the background on your computer. Think of NodeJS like this - if you took the part of the browser that understood Javascript and packaged it all by itself as a separate program then you would essentially have NodeJS.

    https://nodejs.org/en/ (Links to an external site.) - This is the website where you can download the program to install. It looks like the image below.

    You will be installing this on both the Windows and the OSX sides of your Macbook. Choose the one on the right. It will be version 6.x 

    Download and run the file. It will walk you through the install process in a wizard like this:

    Then open the Terminal application in OSX or the Command Prompt in Windows and enter this command

    This will tell the NodeJS progam to run and give you back the version of Node which is currently installed on your computer.

    In the image above you can see that I have version 6.2.2 installed.

     

    Previous Previous: First Week Inspirational Videos Next Next: Installing and Configuring Brackets

    Installing and Configuring Brackets

    Brackets is the IDE (Integrated Development Environment) created by Adobe that we will use for all of our HTML, CSS, and Javascript work, as well as a few other things.

    http://brackets.io/ (Links to an external site.) - The website for the free download.

    Just like NodeJS, download and run the file to install Brackets.

    After it is installed we will want to start adding some extensions. In the image above there is a screenshot of Brackets. If you look to the right side you will see an icon that looks like a Lego brick. Click on that to open the extension manager. 

    In the search box of the extension manager type "Emmet". This will be the first extension we need to install.

    Click on the Install button to the right and then the Close button at the bottom. If Brackets needs to restart itself after any extension is added, it will prompt you after you click Close. Let it close and restart itself if needed.

    As you can see from the tabs there are also themes that you can install for Brackets. These will let you customize the colours and fonts used by Brackets.

    Emmet

    Emmet is a great plugin for writing shortcuts for CSS and HTML. You will be using this one a lot in MAD9013.

    Even if you never use anything else in Emmet, you will want to use it to create new blank HTML files. Just type:

    html:5

    Then hit the <tab> key. A new blank HTML template will be created for you.

     

    Introduction to JavaScript and Basic Syntax

    JavaScript Basics

    JavaScript is a programming language which was initially designed to run within a browser and add interactivity to web pages. It allowed you to show and hide things, validate forms, and control user keyboard input. 20 years later it is used in many different locations and for many different purposes. It has become one of the most widely used and in demand languages in the world.

     

    Looking at this list you can see that it is number 3 in the world. (If that's not enough for you - Python, Ruby, and C++ are the only ones on this list that you won't be learning in depth in the MAD&D program).

    So, what does Javascript look like?

    You will see lots of these characters - ( ), { }, [ ]. They always show up in pairs.

    Every command will end with a ;

    You will also be using a thing known as dot notation. It works like this:

    World.Canada.Ottawa.Algonquin.mad9014.students["steve"].talk("Hello Class");

    See the period between each of the objects? That is how you move from one object to the next. What this code is saying is: There is an object called World. Inside that object is another object called Canada. It contains and object called Ottawa, which contains Algonquin. The Algonquin object has something called mad9014. mad9014 contains a list called students. Inside the list called students there is an item called "steve". "steve" has a method called talk( ). The round parentheses means that this is an action that the object can take. We are passing the String "Hello Class" to the talk( ) method so that the "steve" object can use it in some way.

    Now all those objects and methods are just made up by me.

    There are many objects which already exist inside Javascript. Javascript has a limited vocabulary. It only knows certain words. When you talk to the Javascript interpreter you have to use the words that it understands.

    Here is an example of some words that Javascript does understand.

    console.log("Hello class");

    Use Brackets to create a new blank file. Type the above line into the file and save it as hello.js . All Javascript files end with a .js file extension.

    Javascript understands this line. Javascript knows about the console object. The console is the Terminal window. The log( ) method will write things out to the Terminal window. Whatever you write inside the parentheses, as long as it is wrapped inside a set of quotation marks, will be written out to the terminal window when you run this script.

    Testing your Scripts

    For the first few weeks we will be using NodeJS exclusively for running and testing our Javascript. To do this we will have both Brackets and the Terminal / Command Prompt running (depending on whether you are on Mac or Windows).

    In Brackets we will create our Javascript file and save it. Eg: app.js. For now, create a folder called mad9014 and save your Javascript files inside that folder. It can be in your Documents folder or your Desktop. Later on we will be installing a web server and saving our files there.

    In the Terminal we will navigate to our folder where we saved our .js file. 

    cd - stands for Change Directory

    cd ~/Documents/mad9014/

    This command would take me to a folder called mad9014 inside the Documents folder which is inside my user folder on OSX. On Windows I would use the command

    cd C:\users\griffis\Documents\mad9014\

    to reach a similar location.

    The ls command on OSX means LiSt the contents of the current directory. pwd means Present Working Directory - it will give you the full path to your current folder.

    On Windows dir is the Directory command. It does the same thing as ls on OSX. cwd is the Windows equivalent to pwd. It stands for Current Working Directory.

    Once we have reached the correct folder/directory then we can use NodeJS to run our script

    node app.js

    Just type node followed by a space and then the name of the Javascript file.

     

    Variables and DataTypes

    Introduction to variables

    Variables are a common construct in programming languages that are designed to allow you to save values for later use.

    You can think of a variable as an empty box with a label on it. The label becomes the name you use to refer to the box and its contents. Creating an empty box and giving it a name is called declaring a variable.

    var email;

     

    Different types of boxes can hold different types of values. These different types of values are known as datatypes. The three basic simple datatypes in JavaScript are String, Number, and Boolean. Strings are any combination of letters, numbers, and characters wrapped in quotation marks. Booleans are True and False. Numbers are any numeric value with or without a decimal.

    When you want to put some information into your variable this is known as assigning a value to a variable.

    email = "griffis@algonquincollege.com";

    https://youtu.be/zjVFuft1O2Y (Links to an external site.)

    Expressions

    You can combine assignment and declaration into a single line of code if you want.

    var email = "griffis@algonquincollege.com";

    Sometimes you want to combine values either mathematically or by concatenating strings. String concatenation is accomplished with a plus sign.

    domain ="@" + "algonquincollege.com";
    email = "davidst" + domain;

    Any sort of concatenation or mathematical equation or use of methods are known as expressions.

    let and const

    The latest version of JavaScript also has two other keywords that can be used to declare different types of variables - let and const. We will come back to discuss these later.

    Compound Datatypes

    There are also complex datatypes in Javascript. When you save a list, a piece of HTML, or things like a Date in a variable, these are known as complex datatypes. They have more than just a value. These complex types have other properties and methods.

    https://youtu.be/RpU7NezV8PM (Links to an external site.)  

    if statements

    if statements are a common construct in most programming languages. Simply put, they are a way to let your program make decisions based on yes - no questions. 

    if( x == 5 ){  }

    The example above shows a simple if statement. Inside the parentheses is where you put the question you want the program to ask. Everything and anything that you place inside the parentheses will be boiled down to a yes or no answer.

    Javascript uses the concepts of truthy and falsey. A question may not give you an answer which is exactly TRUE or FALSE. So, there are a handful of things that are considered equal to FALSE. Everything else is considered TRUE.

    https://youtu.be/c83OjxNSPos (Links to an external site.)  

    When asking questions, in if statements, comparison operators are used between the values being compared. Greater than, less than, equal to, and so on, are the comparison operators.

    When you need to do things based on both the TRUE and FALSE conditions then you can use an if-else statement.

    if( x > 5 ){
      // the TRUE condition
    }else{
      // the FALSE condition
    }

    At other times you might want to do things based upon multiple possible answers. In these cases we use if - else if - else statements.

    if( x == 3 ){ 
      // if x is equal to 3
    }else if( x == 4 ){
       //if x is equal to 4
    }else{  
      //all other possible answers
    }

    Watch for more information.

    https://youtu.be/-aMw-ygyI3g (Links to an external site.)  

    Ternary Operators

    https://youtu.be/_lEgIImHoM4 (Links to an external site.)

    Week 2 Summary

     

    Learning Objective: By the end of this week, students will have demonstrated the following: How to use Arrays, Objects, and Loops in JavaScript. 

     

    Prior to Class During Class Following Class
    • Install Brackets on both OSs
    • Install NodeJS on both OSs
    • Start CodeSchool JavaScript lessons
    • Complete Bootcamp install
    		 The learning activities for this week will include:
    • Lectures about programming concepts
    • Practice working with datatypes, variables, and if statements
    • Lectures and code practice with arrays
    • Lectures and code practice with objects
    • Lectures and practice with loops
    • Read all the content from this week's module
    • Review all Tutorial material (video & text)
    • Read the Summary for next week
    • Complete more JavaScript lessons

       

       

       

       

       

       

       

       

       

      Week 2 Resources

      Mozilla Developer Network (MDN) JavaScript References

      https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Statements (Links to an external site.) - Statements and Declarations

      https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Operators (Links to an external site.) - Expressions and Operators

       

      Arrays - https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array (Links to an external site.) 

      (use the left menu to access all the Array methods and properties)

      for loop - https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Statements/for (Links to an external site.) 

       

      for..in loop - https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Statements/for...in (Links to an external site.) 

       

      Dot notation

      Dot notation is a way to access objects inside of other objects as well as their properties and methods.

      console.log( ) is an example you have already seen.

      Here are a couple imaginary examples of dot notation:

      Ottawa.Algonquin.mad9013.students.Dory.swim( );
      Ottawa.Algonquin.mad9013.students.Dory.speak( "Just keep swimming" );

      Each dot separates the objects as you drill down through the objects to reach their properties or methods. Each object is acting as a container for the next object in the chain. "Algonquin" exists inside of "Ottawa". "mad9013" exists as an object inside of "Algonquin".  There is a collection of objects called "students" inside the "mad9013" object... and so on.

      swim( ) and speak( ) are both methods. Methods are actions that an object can carry out. We know that they are methods because they have a set of parentheses at the end of the name. 

       

      Previous Previous: Week 2 Resources Next Next: Arrays

      Dot notation

      Dot notation is a way to access objects inside of other objects as well as their properties and methods.

      console.log( ) is an example you have already seen.

      Here are a couple imaginary examples of dot notation:

      Ottawa.Algonquin.mad9013.students.Dory.swim( );
      Ottawa.Algonquin.mad9013.students.Dory.speak( "Just keep swimming" );

      Each dot separates the objects as you drill down through the objects to reach their properties or methods. Each object is acting as a container for the next object in the chain. "Algonquin" exists inside of "Ottawa". "mad9013" exists as an object inside of "Algonquin".  There is a collection of objects called "students" inside the "mad9013" object... and so on.

      swim( ) and speak( ) are both methods. Methods are actions that an object can carry out. We know that they are methods because they have a set of parentheses at the end of the name. 

       

      Previous Previous: Week 2 Resources Next Next: Arrays

      Arrays

      The Concept

      What is an Array? In the simplest terms, an Array is a list. Just like in real life, you can make a list of anything. A list of numbers, a list of groceries, a list of Prime numbers, a list of random words and numbers, a list of answers to a True or False quiz.

      An Array is a datatype in JavaScript. You can declare a variable and then put an Array in that variable. To access any of the values from the Array you use the variable name and then the index number of the item. The index number is the numeric place within the list. Index numbers in JavaScript Arrays begin with zero.

      var people = ['Jeff Lebowski', 'Han Solo', 'Hermoine Grainger', 'Tony Stark'];
      console.log( people[1] );  //outputs Han Solo

      When you want to add items to an Array you can use the push( ) or unshift( ) methods. push( ) adds the item to the end of the Array. unshift( ) adds the item to the start of the Array - the new item becomes the item at position zero.

      To remove an item from an Array you can use the pop( ) or shift( ) methods. pop( ) will remove the last item in the Array. shift( ) will remove the first item from the Array. All the items in the Array will then shift down by one index position.

      people.push('Peter Weyland');  //added to the end of the array
      var removed = people.pop();
      people.unshift('Peter Weyland');  //added to the start of the array
      removed = people.shift( );    //removed will hold the String 'Peter Weyland'

       

      https://youtu.be/arIhhRd1RPc (Links to an external site.)  

      When you want to remove something from the ANY position in the Array you would use the splice( ) method. The splice( ) method also allows you to inject new items into your array.

      people.splice(0, 2);   //removes the first two items. Start at index 0 and remove 2.
      people.splice(2, 1);   //remove only the item at position 2
      people.splice(2, 0, 'Xander Kane', 'Bilbo Baggins'); //add the two names at positions 2, 3 without removing any
      people.splice(3, 1, 'Gandalf the Grey'); //remove the name at position 3 and replace it with Gandalf

      If you want to find an item in an Array then you can use indexOf( ) or lastIndexOf( ). They will both search the array for the item you provide and return the index of the item in the Array. If the item is not found then it will return -1.

      If you want to sort an Array into alphabetical order then you can call the sort( ) method. The reverse( ) method will reverse the order of the items in your Array. 

      people.sort( );
      people.reverse( ); //Now the array is in reverse alphabetical order

      https://youtu.be/C3EPTuXKRw0 (Links to an external site.)  

      Objects

      An Object is the base object used to create all other objects in JavaScript. The cool thing about them is that you can create your own Objects and give them any properties or methods you want to create.

      To create a new empty Object:

      var phone = { };

      The syntax is similar to creating a new empty Array, but instead of square brackets we use curly braces.

      One similarity between Arrays and Objects is that you can think of them both as lists. 

      The difference is that Arrays are numbered lists and Objects are lists where you give labels to each item.

      var phone = {'type':'cell', 'number':'613-123-4321', 'manufacturer':'Samsung' };

      This sample has three items. The property names are type, number, and manufacturer. The values are 'cell', '613-123-4321', and 'Samsung'.

      To access the properties we can use two different syntaxes.

      var type = phone['type'];
      //OR
      var type = phone.type;

      The Array-like syntax or dot notation both work to either set or get the values.

      phone.number = '613-546-8939';
      phone['manfacturer'] = 'LG';
      var key = 'type';
      phone[key] = 'Cell';

       

      IF the label is stored in a variable, you MUST use the Array-like syntax though.

       

      https://youtu.be/kZjJqm_VIGQ (Links to an external site.)

       

      One last important thing to remember about Objects is that you can put them inside of Arrays or you can put Arrays inside Objects.

      var contacts = [ {'name':'Carrie Fisher', 'number':'405-675-9878'}, {'name':'James Woods', 'number':'604-774-9273'} ];

      The above is an example of an Array that is holding two objects

      var fish = ['Shark', 'Tuna', 'Cod', 'Mackeral'];
      var dogBreeds = ['Labrador', 'Great Dane', 'Boxer' ];
      var animals = {"dogs": dogBreeds, "fishSpecies": fish};

      This example is an Object holding two Arrays.

       

      Loops

      Another common feature in programming languages is the concept of loops. Say, for example, that you wanted to create a list of five random numbers. You could declare five variables and use the Math.random( ) method to generate the numbers and assign them to the variables. We could do this with just repeating the same line of code five times.

      var num1 = Math.random( );
      var num2 = Math.random( );
      var num3 = Math.random( );
      var num4 = Math.random( );
      var num5 = Math.random( );

      While a bit tedious, you can do this without too much effort.

      Now, imagine that you need to save a thousand random numbers, or ten thousand. That would be a LOT of code to write. Loops are a programmatic way of accomplishing a similar task in a repetitive manner with minimal code. Here is an example that would generate 100,000 random numbers and save them all in an Array.

      var nums = [ ];
      for(var i=0; i<100000; i++){
        nums.push( Math.random( ) );
      } 

      That's it. Four lines of code. 100,000 random numbers generated and saved in an Array.

      There are a variety of different types of loops in JavaScript. Here are some videos outlining some of these.

       

      for loops

      for(var i=0; i < 10; i++){
        console.log( i );
      }

      https://youtu.be/CidzYW-8I7s (Links to an external site.)  

      for in loops

      for( prop in myObject ){
        console.log( myObject[prop] );
      }

       

      https://youtu.be/prl73KRkB34 (Links to an external site.)  

      while loops

      There are two kinds of while loops in JavaScript, the while loop and the do..while loop. The difference between them is that the do..while loop will always run at least once because it runs the loop before checking to see if the while test passes. The while loop will test your condition before it runs the loop.

      var counter = 0;
      while(counter < 10){
        console.log(counter);
        counter++;
      } 

      var counter2 = 0;
      do{
        console.log(counter2);
        counter2++;
      }while(counter2 < 10);

      https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Statements/while (Links to an external site.)

          functions

          The Concept

          A function is a collection of JavaScript commands.

          If you have a series of things that you want your program to do, in a specific order, and you want it to be able to repeat that series of steps then you would bundle them together in a function.

          Sometimes you will want your function to calculate something and return an answer. Sometimes you won't.

          Sometimes you will need to provide extra information to the function. Sometimes you won't.

          A real world example could be - goToTheBeerStore( ). Inside that function are all the instructions and steps you would follow, like: get your wallet; drive your car to the closest store; go inside the store; pick the beer; pay for the beer; and bring the beer home.

          An example return value from goToTheBeerStore( ) could be the beer that you bought.

          An example of extra information to the function could be the type of beer to buy, or how much beer to buy.

          The Syntax 

          In JavaScript a basic function declaration looks like this:

          function sendMessage( msg ){
            console.log( msg );
          }

          The function declaration starts with the keyword function, followed by a name, a set of parentheses, and then a set of curly braces. In the example above, some information is being passed to the function in the form of a variable called msg. That variable is then being used inside the function. This function is returning nothing to us. It didn't need to.

          If we wanted to make this function run we would CALL it like this:

          sendMessage("You are a scruffy looking nerf herder!");

          To call a function just write it's name followed by a set of parentheses. Without the parentheses it will NOT run. 

          IF the function requires information then pass it to the function inside the parentheses.

          https://youtu.be/W6QaDqud66Y (Links to an external site.)

           

          Passing Parameters to Functions

           https://youtu.be/dxbsN6_C5PI (Links to an external site.)  

          Using Return Values from Functions

           https://youtu.be/qed2cjdF-30 (Links to an external site.)  

          Function Expressions vs. Function Declarations

          There are actually two ways of creating functions in your JavaScript code. The first is with Function Declarations. All our examples to this point have been with Function Declarations. 

          The second way is with Function Expressions. These are when you declare a variable and assign a function to that variable. Here is the function expression version of the example at the top of this page.

          var sendMessage = function(msg){
            console.log(msg);
          }

          You would call this function the exact same way as before.

          sendMessage('You are a scruffy looking nerf herder!');

          The only difference is that with a function expression, the function and it's variable MUST be ABOVE the line of code that calls it. With function declarations, the function can be anywhere in your script file.

           

           

           

          Variable Scope

           

          Variables declared in JavaScript with the keyword var have either global scope or local scope.

          Variables declared inside a function are called local variables and can only be seen inside that function.

          Variables declared outside of all functions are called global variables and can be seen, accessed, or updated from anywhere in your code.

           https://youtu.be/FyWdrCZZavQ (Links to an external site.)

          If you try to create a local variable inside a function.

           

          The lastest version of JavaScript - ES6 - provides block level scope. Meaning it has a way to create variables that only exist within your for loop block. or if statement block. For more information on this - var, let, and const

           

           

           

          Variable Hoisting

          How the JavaScript interpreter reads through your code

          https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ngX9CYMaFDk (Links to an external site.)  

          Hoisting is a term used to describe how Javascript treats your declarations when it reads through your script files. 

          The JavaScript interpreter actually reads your file twice. The first time it searches for declarations and HOISTS all those declarations to the top of your file, or to the top of the function if they are inside a function.

          After the declarations have all been hoisted to the top of the page or function, it means that ALL the variables are now "undefined". Function declarations that have been hoisted to the top include all their code as part of the declaration.

          Function expressions are actually made of two parts - the variable declaration and the assignment of an anonymous function to that variable name. So, in the first pass made by the interpreter, the variable declaration is hoisted to the top and left as undefined, while the function is left behind in it's original position.

           

          The second pass by the interpreter allows for the assignment of the values and the use of the variables in the order that you have written them in your code. This means that things in your code could fail if you are not aware of this order of operations in your code.

          var firstName = 'Devon';
          console.log(firstName + ' ' + lastName);
          var lastName = 'McKenna';

          So, in the code sample above there will be no syntax or runtime errors. 

          The interpreter would output:

          Devon undefined

          The lastName variable will be hoisted to the top of the page. The console.log method will be aware that there is a variable called lastName but it's value will be undefined when it runs. It's only after the console.log method that the value gets assigned to lastName.

          var, let, and const

          Add "use strict" to allow you to use these in as many places as possible

          var - old way of declaring global or local (function scoped) variables

          let - new way of declaring global or block scoped variables

           

          const - global or block scoped variables that are immutable. You cannot reassign the variable to a new value.

          convention is to use capitalized names

          const NETWORK_ERROR = 0;

          const TIMEOUT_ERROR = 1;

          store the error codes in a constant that can't be changed. Easier than remembering the numbers.

          https://youtu.be/HukePwm-XG8 (Links to an external site.)  

          String Objects

          All Objects have a .toString( ) method which allow you to convert the value of your variable into a String equivalent.

          let num = 3.14;
          let alive = true;
          console.log( num.toString() );  //will output "3.14"
          console.log( alive.toString() ); //will output "TRUE"

          The plus sign operator is used to both add Numbers as well as concatenate Strings. Because of them both using "+" be careful to convert your Strings to Numbers first if you want to concatenate them and convert your Strings to Numbers first if you want to add them.

          let a = 10.5;
          let b = "3.25";
          console.log( a + b );  //outputs "10.53.25"

          String Methods

          For all the following examples assume that we have the following variables:

          let myStringA = "Alexander";
          let myStringB = "A";
          let myStringC = "a";
          let myStringD = "z";

           Note in the comments that these methods "return" values. They do not output these values. They also do not alter the original string. They return a new version of the string with the changes made or they return a number.

          myStringA.indexOf(myStringB);  //returns 0
          myStringA.indexOf(myStringC);  //returns 4
          myStringA.indexOf(myStringD);  //returns -1

          indexOf( ) -returns the position in the original string of whatever parameter you pass it. Ref. - https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/String/indexOf (Links to an external site.) 

          myStringA.lastIndexOf(myStringB);  //returns 0
          myStringA.lastIndexOf("e");  //returns 7
          myStringA.lastIndexOf(myStringD);  //returns -1

          lastIndexOf( ) - does the same thing as indexOf except that it starts looking on the right side. 

          "  hello   ".trim( );  //returns "hello"

          trim( ) - removes any extra whitespace on the left or right of the string. Note that you can call String methods using a String literal instead of a variable. Ref. - https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/String/Trim (Links to an external site.) 

          myStringA.split("e"); // returns a 3 part array ["Al", "xand", "r"]

          split( separator ) - This method creates an Array by splitting up a String into a series of pieces. The interpreter will search through the string for the separator. Whenever the separator string is found, it is removed and another part is cut off the string. Ref. - https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/String/split (Links to an external site.) 

          myStringA.substr(0, 4);  //returns 4 characters starting at position zero. "Alex"

          substr( ) - Returns a partial string from inside the main one (the variable on the left). It starts at the position specified as the first parameter. The second parameter is the length of the string to return. Ref. - https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/String/substr (Links to an external site.) 

          myStringA.substring(2, 4); //returns from position 2 up to but not including position 4

          substring( ) - works the same way as substr( ) except that you specify the ending position instead of a length. With the number 4 entered as the second parameter the substring will include the character at position 3 but will stop before returning position 4. Ref. - https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/String/substring (Links to an external site.) 

          myStringA.slice(3, 8);  //returns the substring "xand". position 3 up to but not including position 7

          slice( ) -  Just like substr( ) and substring( ) allows you to extract part of a string using two index numbers. The starting position gives you the first character. The ending position will not be included. It just tells you where to stop. Ref. - https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/String/slice (Links to an external site.) 

          myStringA.toUpperCase();   //returns "ALEXANDER"

          toUpperCase( ) - simply converts all the characters in the string to upper case ones.

          myStringA.toLowerCase();   //returns "alexander"

          toLowerCase( ) - converts all the characters in the string to lower case ones.

          myStringA.replace(myStringB, myStringC);  //returns new version of the string
          //with any "A" changed to "a"

          replace( ) - will replace any instance of one string with another one that you provide. It can also be used in combination with Regular Expressions. Ref - https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/String/replace (Links to an external site.) 

          Regular Expressions is a more advanced topic for another day. However, I encourage you to read about them - https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/RegExp (Links to an external site.) 

          myStringA.charAt( 4 );   //returns 4

          charAt( index ) - returns the character from the string found at position "index". Ref - https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/String/charAt (Links to an external site.) 

          myStringA.charCodeAt( 0 );    //returns 65

          str.charCodeAt( index ) - returns the Unicode value of the character at position "index".

          String.fromCharCode(65, 66, 67);  //returns a new String "ABC"

          String.fromCharCode(code, code, code, code...) - returns a string built from the Unicode values. Note that it uses the String Object to call this method, not a variable. Ref. - https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/String/fromCharCode (Links to an external site.) 

          myStringA.concat(" ", "Mckenna");  //creates a new string "Alexander Mckenna"

          concat( ) - concatenates different strings just like "+" would. It is more efficient behind the scenes than the "+" is. If you have a program that does lots of string concatenation then you should use the concat method. You can provide as many strings as you want to the method. Just put a comma between each one and they will all be combined.

          If you want to combine  a bunch of variables without having to create a string variable first you can do this:

          "".concat(vara, varb, varc, vard);

          The two double quotes at the beginning create an empty string and everthing else is added to that. Ref. - https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/String/concat (Links to an external site.) 

          Introductory Video

          https://youtu.be/UWLd1tf11e8 (Links to an external site.)  

           

          Numeric and Mathematical Methods

          Global Numerical Methods

          There are a number of methods which can be called globally. This means that you do not have to place an object and a dot in front of the method call. Just call the method directly.

          parseInt(str, base);  //returns a string representation of the integer.
          //The second parameter is the radix, or base. This means you can convert the integer 
          //to binary (base 2), octal (base 8), decimal (base 10), or hexidecimal (base 16)
          //The base can be entered as any number between 2 and 36
          parseFloat(str); //returns a string representation of the decimal number.

          MDN reference for Global Objects - https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects (Links to an external site.)  (look for the heading Function properties)

          Methods called by Number objects

          When you have variables that are of datatype Number, there are a variety of methods that you can call on these variables.

          num.toFixed(2); //round off the number to a specific number of decimal points
          //Method returns a STRING
          num.parseInt( ); //convert the number to an integer.
          //Method returns an integer
          num.isNaN( ); //check if the number in the variable is Not A Number (NaN)
          //returns a true or false (Boolean)
          num.isInteger( ); //checks if the value in the variable is an integer.
          //returns true or false. False if the number has decimals  eg:  3.14

          MDN reference for Number objects - https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Number (Links to an external site.)  

          Mathematical methods

          JavaScript has a Math object which can carry out most common mathematical operations. If you need to round numbers up or down, complete Trigonometric calculations, determine which is the largest or smallest number, create a random number, determine if a number is positive or negative, or access the value of Î . All of these things can be accomplished with the Mathematical methods.

          These methods all begin with the Math object.

          Math.round(num); //returns the next highest or lowest integer depending on its decimal value.
          Math.floor(num); //always rounds down to the next lowest integer
          Math.ceil(num); //always rounds up to the next highest integer
          Math.random( ); //returns a random value between 0 and 1.
          Math.max(list, of, numbers); //returns the largest number from the list
          Math.min(list, of, numbers); //returns the smallest number from the list
          Math.abs(num); //returns the absolute value of the number
          Math.sign(num)  //returns 1, -1, 0, -0, NaN to tell you if the number is positive or negative
          Math.sin(radians); //returns the sine value for the provided radian value
          Math.cos(radians); //returns the value of Cosine for the provided radian value
          Math.tan(radians); //returns the value of Tangent for the provided radian value
          Math.PI;  //Use this as if it were a variable holding the value of Pi

          https://youtu.be/qg--kxKnBCE (Links to an external site.)  

          And there are many more Numeric and Mathematical methods available. I encourage you to read through the list on the MDN site.

          Number reference - https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Number (Links to an external site.)

          Math reference - https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Math (Links to an external site.) 

          Global Method reference - https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects (Links to an external site.) 

          More Array Methods

          Array.forEach

          A fairly new method belonging to JavaScript Arrays, which allows for looping through each element in the array without having to create a for loop, a for..in loop, or a while loop.

          Array.forEach( function(item, index, array){   
            //functionality to be called once for each item in the array
          } );

          https://youtu.be/159EAISAxwg (Links to an external site.)

          forEach reference - https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/forEach (Links to an external site.) 

          Array.map

          The Array map( ) method is very similar to the forEach method, in that it allows you to loop through the array and do something for each element in the Array. 

          The primary difference is that the map( ) method will let you create a new array based on things that you do to the old elements. The forEach( ) method will return "undefined". The map( ) method returns a new Array. 

          The function that you pass to the map( ) method must have a return statement. Each of the return values are what will be placed inside the new Array.

          let newArray = myArray.map( function(item, index, array){  
            return item.toUpperCase();
          } );
          //newArray will contain all the uppercase versions of the elements in myArray.

          https://youtu.be/hfYa4ugeyuc (Links to an external site.)  

          map reference - https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/map (Links to an external site.) 

           

          Function practice

          Re-submit Assignment
          • Due Sep 27 by 8am
          • Points 5
          • Submitting a file upload
          • File Types js

          Complete the code in the attached JS file, according to the instructions in the comments.

          function-exercise.js

          The file can be run and tested from the terminal using NodeJS. 

          There is a function to calculate the total gross pay, net pay, taxes, regular hours, and overtime hours for an employee. When the function is called you must pass in two values - the hours worked for each of two weeks.

          In your code you need to take the hours for the first week and determine how many hours of overtime were worked and how many regular hours were worked. Calculate the gross pay by multiplying the hours worked and by the overtime multiplier for overtime hours. Once you have the total for the gross pay then calculate the taxes. subtract the taxes from the gross pay to determine the total net pay.

          Each of the values for maximum hours per week, tax rate, hourly wage are held in global constants. 

          There should be nothing where you enter numbers in your code. Use the variables and constants in all your calculations.

          Once you have completed and tested your function, add two more calls to the function at the bottom of your page. After each call to the function, repeat the console.log statement being used to output the paycheque information.

          The final output from your function will show 4 console log outputs with different hours worked in each of the 8 weeks.

           

          Here is an example of what the final output could look like. 

          The values for the third and fourth paycheques will be different for yours.

            Running JavaScript in the Browser

            When you want to add JavaScript files to your web pages you will need to use script tags.

             <script src="myscript.js"></script>

            The recommended place to add your scripts is inside the body element, after all your other HTML.

            <body>
              <script src="myscript.js"></script>
            </body>

            https://youtu.be/fWDVDm4HRwA (Links to an external site.)  

             

            Another recommended feature that you can add to your script tag is the async attribute. This will tell modern browsers to wait until all your HTML has loaded before trying to run your script.

             

            Previous Previous: JS Quiz I Next Next: Working with the DOM

            Working with the DOM

            The DOM is the Document Object Model. This is the reference model for how the JavaScript interpreter views your web page.

            Your web page is made up of Element Nodes, Attribute Nodes, and Text Nodes.

            There are actual 13 types of Nodes including Comment Nodes and Document Declarations but through our JavaScript it will be quite rare to do anything other than manipulate elements, attributes and text nodes.

            let element = document.getElementById("bob");
            element.textContent = "Hello!"

            As a simple example, the code sample above would search through a web page for an element with the id "bob" and then change the text inside of it to read "Hello!".

            https://youtu.be/O6BNfJz3rgs (Links to an external site.)
            Minimize Video              

             document and document.body

            document is a keyword that represents the current web page. It contains a long list of properties and methods that you can use to find things out about the current page.

            One of the most common properties that you will use in JavaScript is document.body it is a keyword that represents the <body> element in the current webpage.

            MDN reference for document.body - https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Document/body (Links to an external site.) - look to the left-hand menu for the other properties and methods.

             

             

            Previous Previous: Running JavaScript in the Browser Next Next: Properties, Methods, and Events

            Properties, Methods, and Events

            Objects in Javascript can have properties, methods, and events

            properties - things that can be measures about the object

            Array.length, ElementNode.id, ElementNode.classList, ElementNode.textContent

             

            methods - things that the object can do (actions) identified by the parentheses

            Array.sort( ), ElementNode.getAttribute("title"), document.getElementById( id )

             

            events - things that can happen to the objects. We are most interested in the DOM Events

            click, mouseover, mouseout, mousemove, dblclick, unload, load, blur, focus
            Previous Previous: Working with the DOM Next Next: querySelector, querySelectorAll, getElementById

            querySelector, querySelectorAll, getElementById

            When you want to make changes to a webpage or read the contents of a webpage with JavaScript then you need a way of locating elements. The three methods that you will use most frequently when accessing web page content are:

            let element = document.querySelector( cssSelector );  //returns a single element node
            let nodes = document.querySelectorAll( cssSelector );  //returns a NodeList
            let element = document.getElementById( id );   //returns a single element node

            querySelector( ) and getElementById( ) search the webpage for the first element node that matches. 

            let anchor = document.querySelector(".main p a");

            In the example above, the variable anchor will contain either null, if no match found, or the first anchor tag inside a paragraph inside an element with the className ".main". You can pass ANY valid CSS selector, as a string, to this method.

            let foot = document.getElementById("footer");

            In this example, the variable foot will contain either null or the element on the page that has the id "footer". You pass any string that should match an id of an element on your page.

            querySelectorAll( ) will return a NodeList, which is similar to an Array in that it is a numbered list, but it can only contain HTML Nodes. When you call querySelectorAll( ), it will ALWAYS return a NodeList. The NodeList might be empty, but it is still a NodeList.

            let paragraphs = document.querySelectorAll("#main p");

            The above example will return a NodeList containing ALL of the paragraphs inside the element with the id "main". Notice that this is a valid CSS selector, just like the querySelector( ) call above.

            https://youtu.be/DO02UZaedIo (Links to an external site.)  

            NodeList - https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/NodeList (Links to an external site.)

            querySelector - https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Document/querySelector (Links to an external site.) 

            querySelectorAll - https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Document/querySelectorAll (Links to an external site.) 

            getElementById - https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Document/getElementById (Links to an external site.) 

            textContent -  https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Node/textContent (Links to an external site.) 

            Previous Previous: Properties, Methods, and Events Next Next: createElement, createTextNode, appendChild

            createElement, createTextNode, appendChild

            Document Methods

            document.createElement('p');  //creates an Element Node of the type provided
            document.createTextNode('hello world');  //creates a TextNode 

            https://youtu.be/an-6owXUwdg (Links to an external site.)

            Node Properties

            In the list below there are a series of property pairs. The first properties will return a NodeList or a single Node.  Remember that Nodes can be element nodes, text nodes, or comments.

            The second property will return a list of Element Nodes or a single Element Node.

            node.childNodes v node.children
            node.firstChild v. node.firstElementChild
            node.lastChild v. node.lastElementChild
            node.nextSibling v. node.nextElementSibling
            node.previousSibling v. node.previousElementSibling
            node.parentNode v. node.parentElement

            These last three node properties return a single piece of information about the node.

            node.nodeName;  //returns the tagname, if an element node
            node.nodeType;  //returns the integer referencing the type of node. Eg: 1=element, 3=text
            node.nodeValue;  //returns the string inside a text node

            Node Methods

            parentNode.appendChild(newNode); //add a new child node inside the parent
            parentNode.removeChild(childNode);  //remove the child from the parent
            node.replaceChild(newNode);  //replace one node with a new one
            parentNode.contains(node);  //checks if the node is a descendant of the parent
            node.hasChildNodes( );  //returns a boolean indicating if the node has child nodes
            node.hasAttributes( );  //returns a boolean if the node has attributes
            parentNode.insertBefore(newNode, referenceNode); //inserts a new node into the DOM 
            //immediately before the reference node

            https://youtu.be/Pr4LLrmDLLo (Links to an external site.)  

            Element Properties

            let c = element.className;  //get or set the value of the class attribute
            let list = element.classList; //get the list of classnames assigned to the element
            element.classList.add(className);
            element.classList.remove(className);
            element.innerHTML = '<p>New paragraph</p>'; //add a new document fragment as a
            //replacement child for the element's current child nodes
            let nm = element.tagName;  //retrieve the HTML element's tag name eg: P, LI, A, DIV

            https://youtu.be/Omwn8hGpDYs (Links to an external site.)

            getting and setting Attributes

            When working with an Element you will often want to read the value from or update an attribute within that Element.

            Element properties concerning Attributes

            element.attributes //returns a list of the attributes in the element

             

            Element methods concerning Attributes

            element.getAttribute(attrName);
            element.setAttribute(attrName, attrValue);
            element.hasAttributes( );
            element.hasAttribute(attrName);
            element.removeAttribute(attrName);

            Styling HTML with JavaScript

            Cascading Style Sheets (CSS) are the way to control the presentation of your HTML content in the browser. Your CSS files should always be external files that you link to your webpage.

            Now, although you can, you would never want to set every single CSS property for each HTML Element through your JavaScript. 

            However, that doesn't mean that there will not be times when you need to or want to update specific CSS properties for your page, from within your script.

            element.className = newClass;
            element.classList; 
            element.classList.add(); 
            element.classList.remove();
            element.classList.toggle();
            element.style.backgroundColor = "blue";
            element.style.cssText = "color:white; background-color:blue;";
            let styleDeclaration = window.getComputedStyle(element); 
            styleDeclaration.cssText = "color:white; background-color:blue"; 
            styleDeclaration.length; 
            styleDeclaration.item(0).getPropertyValue('color'); 
            styleDeclaration.item(0).setProperty(prop, value); 
            styleDeclaration.item(0).removeProperty(prop);

            https://youtu.be/h1_BBMGJjUA (Links to an external site.)  

            MDN references

            classList - https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Element/classList (Links to an external site.)

            className - https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Element/className (Links to an external site.) 

            getComputedStyle - https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/getComputedStyle (Links to an external site.) 

            style -  https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/HTMLElement/style (Links to an external site.)

              XML Data Files

              XML is a data format that is designed to be human readable first.

              It is a markup language like HTML except you get to decide on the tags yourself.

              Most importantly, it is for DATA NOT PRESENTATION.

              https://youtu.be/CiXeEkbj_yg (Links to an external site.) 

              Official reference for XML - https://www.w3.org/standards/xml/ (Links to an external site.)  

              There are four special characters that need to always be handled in your XML files - <, >, &, and ". These four must be written as character entities - &lt; &gt; &amp; and &quot;

              Lynda.com video about working with data formats like XML and JSON - https://www.lynda.com/CSS-tutorials/Working-Data-Web/133326-2.html (Links to an external site.) 

              XML Data Files

              XML is a data format that is designed to be human readable first.

              It is a markup language like HTML except you get to decide on the tags yourself.

              Most importantly, it is for DATA NOT PRESENTATION.

              https://youtu.be/CiXeEkbj_yg (Links to an external site.) 

              Official reference for XML - https://www.w3.org/standards/xml/ (Links to an external site.)  

              There are four special characters that need to always be handled in your XML files - <, >, &, and ". These four must be written as character entities - &lt; &gt; &amp; and &quot;

              Lynda.com video about working with data formats like XML and JSON - https://www.lynda.com/CSS-tutorials/Working-Data-Web/133326-2.html (Links to an external site.) 

              Reading XML with JavaScript

              XML and JSON files can be loaded into the browser via an AJAX call. These are controlled by JavaScript. See the module 7 for details about HOW to load these data files into memory with JavaScript. 

              This page will focus on how we can read the contents of an XML file after it has been loaded via JavaScript.

              XML can be treated as if it were HTML without any ids or classes. We will use a variety of properties and methods to access the contents of the XML elements and attributes and text nodes.

              let chars = document.getElementsByTagName("character");
              //This will give us a collection of all the <character> elements
              let firstChar = document.getElementsByTagName("character")[0];  
              //This will give us the FIRST character element
              let secondChar = firstChar.nextSibling;
              //This will give us the SECOND character element

              Here is a sample XML file which is stored on GitHub (see the link below). It has one root tag <data>. <movie> is a child of <data>. <characters> is a child of <movie>. <characters has a series of childElementNodes, each called <character>.

              <movie> has three attributes - id, title, and imdb-url. These could have been elements but I decided to make them attributes instead. It makes the XML a little smaller when you use attributes too.

              We can move around inside the XML, fetching different elements by using:

              let char = document.getElementsByTagName("character")[0];
              let chars = char.childElementNodes;
              //then loop through each of the chars
              //To get the name TEXT inside the first character (The Dude)
              chars[0].childElementNodes[0].firstChild.nodeValue;
              //childElementNodes[0] - the <name> element inside the first <character>
              //firstChild - the text node inside the <name> element
              //nodeValue - the actual text from inside the <name>

              NOTE: A very common error is to get the firstChild inside a node and be expecting that to be text. Instead it is a textNode object. The nodeValue property is the actual text.

              We can use for loops to access each of the elements in order.

              let chars = document.getElementsByTagName("character");
              let numChars = chars.length;
              for(let i=0; i<numChars; i++){
                //write out each of the actor names to the console.
                let actor = chars[i].getElementsByTagName("actor")[0];
                let actorText = actor.firstChild.nodeValue;
                console.log( actorText );
              }

              To fetch the attributes we use the standard getAttribute( ) method on any element node.

              let movie = document.getElementsByTagName("movie")[0];
              let movieId = movie.getAttribute("id");
              let title = movie.getAttribute("title");
              let url = movie.getAttribute("imdb-url");

              The structure of the XML is designed to allow for future additions of more characters or more movies.

              <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<data>
  <movie id="tt0118715" title="The Big Lebowski" imdb-url="http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0118715/?ref_=ttfc_fc_tt">
    <characters>
      <character>
        <name>The Dude</name>
        <actor>Jeff Bridges</actor>
      </character>
      <character>
        <name>Walter Sobchak</name>
        <actor>Dan Goodman</actor>
      </character>
      <character>
        <name>Theodore Donald "Donnie" Kerabatsos</name>
        <actor>Steve Buscemi</actor>
      </character>
      <character>
        <name>Brandt</name>
        <actor>Phillip Seymour Hoffman</actor>
      </character>
      <character>
        <name>Jesus Quintana</name>
        <actor>John Turturro</actor>
      </character>
    </characters>
  </movie>
</data>

              GIST of XML file https://gist.github.com/prof3ssorSt3v3/d6b5eeed6ba12bdc29061e07b05f356a (Links to an external site.) 

               

               

              JSON Data Files

              JSON stands for JavaScript Object Notation. It is similar to XML in that it is a data file format but it is a slightly more compressed format. The reduced size means that your data files are smaller but it also means that they can be a little harder to read.

              https://youtu.be/P2LdhPpqSiU (Links to an external site.)  

              The official reference site for JSON - http://www.json.org/ (Links to an external site.)  

              All the unicode characters can be found on the Unicode charts - http://www.unicode.org/charts/ (Links to an external site.) 

              Lynda.com video about working with data formats like XML and JSON - https://www.lynda.com/CSS-tutorials/Working-Data-Web/133326-2.html (Links to an external site.) 

              Reading JSON with JavaScript

               

              Just like XML files, we can use JavaScript to fetch remote JSON files from a web server and then use the contents of those files as the data to drive our application. See Module 7 for details on the fetching of the data files with AJAX.

              Once we have the file back we will be given the contents of the JSON file as a STRING, not an actual JavaScript Object. We need to convert the string into an object. This is a achieved with the JSON object.

              let dataObject = JSON.parse( stringFromFile );

              In the example above dataObject will now be an actual object that we can use in our code. We can read it's properties and loop through its arrays.

              Let's say we have this JSON data in our dataObject variable:

              { "movies": [
                {"id": "tt0295297", "title":"Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets", "imdb-url":"http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0295297/", "characters":[
                  {"name":"Harry Potter", "actor":"Daniel Radcliffe"},
                  {"name":"Hermoine Grainger", "actor":"Emma Watson"},
                  {"name":"Ron Weasley", "actor":"Rupert Grint"} ] 
                } ]
              }

              It's similar to the data we were using in our XML example, except that it is a lot more condensed. We don't have opening and closing tags. The list of characters is just an array of objects.  The movies property is an array it is also a top level property of our dataObject variable.

              To loop through our list of characters for this movie and console log out the actor's names:

              let movie = dataObject.movies[0];
              console.log('Characters in', movie.title);
              for(let i=0, numChars=movie.characters.length; i<numChars; i++){
                console.log( movie.characters[i].actor );
              }

               Notice that I added the declaration and  assignment of numChars inside the initialization area of our for loop. This way it only exists during the loop and only gets calculated once.

              Same effect as with the XML, just less code.

               

              Looping through Objects

              If you needed to loop through all the properties in the first movie but didn't know the names of the properties then we can use the for..in loop.

              let movie = dataObject.movies[0];
              for(let prop in movie ){
                console.log("Property name is", prop);
                console.log("Property value is", movie[prop] );
              }

              We just use the square bracket syntax instead of the dot notation. This way we can use the variable as the property name.

               

              Stringify

              If you ever need to convert a JavaScript object into a string, there is also a stringify method.

              let strData = JSON.stringify( dataObject );

               

               

              Nested Loops for Complex Objects

              There will be times when you have a complex object that has arrays nested inside of arrays. When you need to loop through all of the elements at every level, we will use a nested loop.

              Take this data as our example:

              var pets = {"animals":[
                {"dogs" : [ "Woody", "Roxy" ] },
                {"cats" : [ "Willow", "Jesse Pink-kitty", "Bob" ] }
              ] }

              In this object, animals is an array of objects. Each of the objects inside of animals has a property which is an array.

              We want to be able to write out all these pet names dynamically in a format that looks like this:

              dogs
                  Woody
                  Roxy
              cats
                  Willow
                  Jesse Pink-kitty
                  Bob

               

              So, a nested loop... That means a loop inside of a loop.

              let animals = pets.animals;  //our first array
              for(let a=0, numAnimals=animals.length; a<numAnimals; a++){
                  for(let prop in animals[a]){
                      //this will only loop once and get us the property name
                      console.log( prop );
                      //now get all the pet names for this prop (dogs or cats)
                      for(let i=0, numPets=animals[a][prop].length; i<numPets; i++){
                          console.log( "\t", animals[a][prop][i] );
                          //add the \t to indent one tab
                      }
                  }
              }

              Here we used a loop inside a loop inside a loop. The second loop was necessary because our array was hidden behind a property name. If we only had an array of arrays then two loops would be all that was required.
