                Event Listeners

                JavaScript is largely event-driven. Now, if you have never programmed with events before, that can seem like a pretty meaningless statement. So, let's break this statement down into smaller parts.

                What is a Browser Event

                A browser event is something that happens when a user interacts with a web page or some activity in the browser starts or ends. Examples of events: an image finishes loading; the browser finishes rendering the HTML of the current page; a data file has been brought back from a remote location; the user clicks on an HTML element; the user scrolls a webpage; the user presses a key on the keyboard. All of these things are events.

                What is Event-Driven

                When events are the trigger that starts your functions running it means that you are programming in an event-driven manner.

                Take the list of event examples from the previous paragraph, and add this phrase in front of each one, "you have a function that runs when".

                What is an Event Listener

                The final part of this process is creating Event Listeners. An event listener is an object that sits in the background, attached to the web page, waiting for a specific type of event to occur. It is the glue between the event and the function that you want to run.

                Here is an example that will change the background colour of an h1 element to gold when the user clicks on it.

                let h1 = document.querySelector("header h1");
                h1.addEventListener("click", highlight);

                function highlight(ev){
                  ev.target.style.backgroundColor = "goldenrod";
                }

                The first line just finds the element to which you want to attach the listener.

                The second line creates the event listener object. It adds the event listener object to the h1 element and tells the event listener to listen for a "click" event. The second parameter in the addEventListener method is the name of a function to call when the event occurs.

                Inside the function declaration there is a variable called ev. This variable will be passed the click event when the function gets called. The event object contains a number of properties that can be quite useful. One of these properties is target. ev.target is the object with the event listener which called the function. 

                In our example above ev.target is the local variable version of the h1 variable. We can also use the keyword this as equivalent to ev.target.

                Anonymous Functions

                Another way of writing the code example from above would be with an anonymous (unnamed) function. Just replace the name of the function with the anonymous function declaration.

                let h1 = document.querySelector("header h1");
                h1.addEventListener("click", function(ev){
                  ev.target.style.backgroundColor = "goldenrod";
                }); 

                This code will run the exact same way as the version above. 

                The difference between the two is that the named function can be reused. It can be called by other parts of your code.

                Leave Off the Parentheses

                One very important part of the syntax here is that when we add the name of the function we must omit the parentheses at the end of the function name. If we leave the parentheses at the end of the name then JavaScript will immediately run the function and it is the result of the function that will be attached by the event listener.

                var h1 = document.querySelector("header h1");
                h1.addEventListener("click", setBold() );     //this is BAD

                var h2 = document.querySelector("header h2");
                h2.addEventListener("click", setBold );      //this is GOOD

                function setBold(ev){
                  ev.target.style.fontWeight = "900";
                }

                When the user clicks on the h1 element nothing will happen. In fact, as soon as the page loads we will have a JavaScript error that prevents your code from running. The second line of code will actually run the function setBold as soon as it is read. That means there is no ev object being passed. Since ev is undefined in our function, its first line will fail because it cannot find a property called target inside of undefined. The h2 version would work just fine, if not for the error.

                So, remember to omit the parentheses.

                 

                Removing Event Listeners

                There will be times when you want to remove an event listener. Maybe you are building something that is intended to be clicked only once. So, you want to add the event listener but the first time the function is called you want to remove the listener so the function doesn't get called a second time.

                The syntax is almost the exact same as the addEventListener method.

                let li = document.querySelector(".mainnav li:first-child");
                li.removeEventListener("click", slide );

                As long as you have a reference to the element that has the listener, you can remove it. You just pass the event type and the name of the function to the removeEventListener method.

                We need to pass both parameters because we can add an unlimited number of listeners to any element. We need to be specific about which one to remove.

                let li = document.querySelector(".mainnav li:first-child");
                li.addEventListener("mouseover", bounce );
                li.addEventListener("click", slide );
                li.addEventListener("mousedown", wobble );
                li.addEventListener("mouseout", hum );
                li.addEventListener("mousemove", spin );
                li.removeEventListener("click", slide );

                 This example shows multiple listeners being added to the same object and then only ONE of them being removed.

                 

                Preventing Link and Form Problems

                When you click a link or submit a form the browser wants to take over and actually load a new page in the browser or actually send the form off to the web server. If you want to run your own code and prevent the browser from reloading the current page then we need to add a call to the preventDefault method in our event function.

                let a = document.querySelector("mainnav a"); //first link in our main nav
                a.addEventListener("click", doSomethingCool );

                function doSomethingCool(ev){
                  ev.preventDefault( );
                  ev.target.style.textDecoration = 'strike-through';
                }

                This example will prevent the browser from taking the user to the new page by calling the preventDefault method. The preventDefault method is another one of the things built into the Event object passed to the function.

                 

                 

                Forcing Events to Happen

                There will be times when you want to trigger one of your event listeners in your code without the user doing anything.

                Let's say that you have a function that you are using to display and highlight a message on the screen. In most cases this function is being called when the user clicks a button. You have an event listener attached to the button. That event listener calls the function to display the message and highlight it.

                We decide that we are going to dynamically load a new image and the image load event will have a listener to call some other function. We also want to call the function being used by the button click. If we know the name of the function it is easy to call. However, we will have to write code that handles the event object being missing. 

                So, instead we will tell the browser to pretend that the user clicked on the button. This simulated click will actually trigger the function to display the message and highlight it.

                element.dispatchEvent( eventType );

                This is the basic syntax for making the browser think an event took place.

                 

                DOM Events

                There are many events inside the browser. Most of them are used to track user interaction with the webpage. Others are used to manage the loading and unloading of resources or Errors.

                You can create listeners for any of these events.

                 

                MouseEvents

                click, mousedown, mouseup, mousemove, mouseover, mouseout, focus, blur, dblclick, contextmenu 

                 

                File/Page related Events (images, scripts, html...)

                load, DOMContentLoaded, unload, scroll, resize

                 

                Form Events

                submit, change, focus, blur, select, keydown, keyup, keypress, reset

                 

                Error Event

                error

                 

                Event Bubbling

                HTML elements are nested inside other HTML elements. Parent elements are wrapped around child elements.

                When a mouse event happens to an element it can pass through other elements too. Using this image to demonstrate, think of a user clicking on a button that is on a webpage. The click will either pass from the <button> to the <body> to the <html> element OR it starts at the <html> and travels through the <body> to finally arrive at the <button>

                <html>
                  <head>
                    <title>Event Bubbling</title>
                  </head>
                  <body>
                    <button id="myButton">Click me</button>
                  </body>
                </html>

                By default events bubble up. Looking at the HTML you can see that the <body> and the <html> elements are both ancestors of the <button> and they are also ABOVE the <button>.

                When you add event listeners, there is a third parameter (called useCapture) where we indicate if we want to use the Bubbling phase or the Capture phase when listening for the event.

                let btn = document.getElementById("myButton");
                btn.addEventListener("click", doSomething, false);  //this is the default - bubbling phase

                To use the capture phase we would use true as the value for the third parameter

                btn.addEventListener("click", doSomething, true); //use the capturing phase.

                 

                So, why is this important?

                Using the same page from above, consider this code:

                let html = document.querySelector("html");
                let body = document.querySelector("body");
                let btn = document.querySelector("#myButton");

                html.addEventListener("click", doSomethingA, false);
                body.addEventListener("click", doSomethingB, false);
                btn.addEventListener("click", doSomethingC, false);

                When the user clicks the button, ALL THREE functions will run. The event will bubble up from the button to the html element.

                The button click - doSomethingC will run first

                Second will be the click on the body - doSomethingB.

                Third will be the click on the html - doSomethingA.

                What if you wanted to run them in the reverse order? doSomethingA, then doSomethingB, then doSomethingC?

                You would have to change the third parameter in all three addEventListener calls to true.

                 

                Stopping Events in Their Tracks

                Here is another situation using the same three event listeners. 

                We want to run the button click first, the body click second, and the html click third.

                However, if the user clicks the button we do NOT want the body or html click to run. We only want the html and body clicks to run if the user clicks somewhere on the page other than on the button.

                event.stopPropagation( )

                The stopPropagation method is what we need here. When called, this method will stop the event from bubbling in either direction.

                Step 1. make sure the events are bubbling from button to body to html

                btn.addEventListener("click", doSomethingC, false);
                body.addEventListener("click", doSomethingB, false);
                html.addEventListener("click", doSomethingA, false);

                Step 2. in the button click function stop the event from going any further.

                function doSomethingC(ev){
                  ev.stopPropagation( );  //prevent the click from bubbling
                  // ... other code ...
                }

                 

                 

                Keyword this

                The keyword this can be a confusing one in JavaScript. It is typically a reference to the object that made a function run.

                For the purposes of this discussion we will limit the use of this to functions triggered by event listeners.

                let btn1 = document.getElementById("myButton");
                let btn2 = document.querySelector(".btn");
                let btn3 = document.querySelector("#otherButton");

                btn1.addEventListener("click", makeNoisy );
                btn2.addEventListener("click", makeNoisy );
                btn3.addEventListener("click", makeNoisy );

                function makeNoisy(ev){
                  ev.target.style.backgroundImage = "url(./img/noisy-pattern.png)";
                }

                In this example we have three different buttons being referenced in the variables btn1, btn2, and btn3.

                All three buttons have a click listener.

                All three click listeners will call the function makeNoisy( ).

                Inside the function makeNoisy, we are able to tell which button needs to have the background image added because ev.target gives us that information. The target property points to the button that was clicked.

                The keyword this works in the same way.

                function makeNoisy( ev ){
                  this.style.backgroundImage = "url(.img/noisy-pattern.png)";
                }

                We can replace ev.target with this.

                This points to the object in front of addEventListener( ).

                 

                Protecting Your Scripts with Namespaces

                As the complexity of your web projects grows, you will eventually run into a situation where you are sharing the code writing duties with another person. You may or may not know the person. You may or may not be in contact with that person. You may just be using a JavaScript file provided to you by a previous employee at your company.

                Now, without opening their 3000 line JavaScript file and looking at all the function names... how can you write your JavaScript file in a way that will never conflict with theirs? How can you be sure that your variable and functions won't collide with theirs?

                The answer is by namespacing your file.

                Come up with a single unique name for your JavaScript. Use that as the name of your first object which will contain ALL your code.

                let STEVE = {
                  version: 1.0,
                  date: "19/10/2016",
                  num: 17,
                  str: 'Hello World',
                  message: function(msg){
                    console.log('STEVE says', msg);
                  }
                };

                If this is my JavaScript file then I have a single object which contains four properties: version, num, str, and date; plus a single method called message.

                To use my code from some other JS file:

                let myMessage = "As of " + STEVE.date + " we are at version " + STEVE.version;
                STEVE.message( myMessage );

                Every time I want to use one of the properties or methods from my file I just prefix them with STEVE. .

                I can now pass my file off to anyone else to use. They can call their variables whatever they like. As long as they avoid one name - STEVE, then we are good to go.

                This process is known as namespacing.

                 

                 

                Controlling Webpages through CSS Classes

                When writing your client-side JavaScript you will often be in a position where you are trying to draw your users attention to some part of the interface. You want them to notice your feedback message. You want to make them notice you just added new content to the page. You want them to realize that something was being removed.

                All of these changes can be thought of as state changes.

                A user being logged in or logged out is a difference in states. 

                Adding something to a shopping cart is a state change.

                Adding new content to a page puts the page in an updated state.

                CSS classes are the best way to reflect these changes. 

                 

                Multiple Team Members

                Once your development team grows beyond a single person you are dividing the responsibilities of the site. Frequently that means one person or group is writing the JavaScript and one person or group is writing the CSS. 

                Having the JavaScript developer changing individual style properties is not only an inefficient use of time, it is also prone to frequent errors and updates.

                The best plan is to have one person working on the CSS using an agreed upon list of CSS class names. Then the other developer can write the JavaScript to add and remove these classes. 

                If changes in CSS classes (STATES) is immediate fine. If we want some type of animated change from one state to the other then the CSS programmer can add CSS transitions. This way the JavaScript developer never has to worry about the implementation details. To them, colour changes and transition animations should not matter. The JavaScript developer should worry about providing feedback to the user, gracefully handling errors, making sure the sequence of events on the page is logical.

                Leave design decisions to the designer.

                 

                JavaScript for State Changes

                We should be using the classList object on the target HTML element.

                let output = document.querySelector(".message");
                output.classList.add("highlighted");
                output.classList.add("fade");
                output.classList.remove("hidden");
                output.classList.toggle("show");

                 

                Use these methods to control your classes on your HTML elements.

                In your CSS you will be able to add transitions to animate these changes.

                .trans{
                  transition: all 1s ease-in-out;
                }
                .fade{
                  opacity: 0;
                }
                .show{
                  opacity: 1;
                } 
                .highlighted{
                  background-color: gold;
                  font-weight: 900;
                }

                 In your HTML you can use multiple class names to combine these styles.

                <div class="message trans highlighted">The output message</div>

                We could keep the classes message and trans on this div at all times. The JavaScript code would control adding or removing the fade, show, and highlighted classes.

                 

                 

                Web APIs and JavaScript Event Loop

                Core JavaScript VS. the Web APIs

                The JavaScript that we use in the browser is actually made up of two different things.

                There is the Core JavaScript that we were using with Node.JS for the first few weeks of the semester and there are the Web APIs.

                The Core part is made up of the features like variables, if statements, functions, data types, arrays, loops, ternary operators, the Math object.

                The Web APIs are all the things that are added on top for the browser - HTML DOM, CSS style manipulation, handling AJAX requests, timers (setTImeout and setInterval), the browser events, geolocation, local storage, and all the features added to support mobile devices.

                 

                The JavaScript Loop

                The JavaScript engines, like Chrome's V8, use a single thread to process all your code. It builds a stack of commands to run, in the order that you have written them. As long as each command belongs to the CORE JavaScript then it gets added to the main run stack. 

                When something that belongs to the Web APIs is encountered it gets added to a secondary list of tasks. Each time the main stack is finished then the JavaScript engine turns it attention to the secondary list of tasks and will try to run those.

                The video below does a great job explaining all the parts of this process. It is about 25 minutes so give yourself some time to watch it.

                You don't need this information to do any of the assignments this semester. However, it will help you to avoid errors in your code and to better understand how your code will be interpreted by the JavaScript engine. This will lead to you writing much better code in the long run.

                 

                Everything you need to know about the JavaScript Loop

                https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8aGhZQkoFbQ (Links to an external site.)

                  Week 7 Resources

                   

                  http://jsonplaceholder.typicode.com/ (Links to an external site.) - test data for AJAX calls (JSON format)

                  https://www.mamp.info/en/downloads/ (Links to an external site.) - download MAMP

                  Introduction to AJAX

                  AJAX is a term coined back in 2005 by Jesse James Garrett. It stands for Asynchronous JavaScript and XML. At that time, XML was the main data format in use for transmitting information in text files. 

                  XML had gained popularity in the late 1990's. JSON didn't even have a name for the standard until 2001. By 2005 XML had become available as a standard in most database implementations and many programming languages. This is why the term AJAX includes XML.

                  Putting aside the XML in the name "AJAX", the concept is quite simple.

                  The ability for JavaScript to send an independent HTTP request to a web server.

                   

                  When you open your browser and type an address into the location bar and hit enter, you are sending an HTTP request to a web server. The browser sends the request, and when it receives the response back from the Server, it will display that file for you to view.

                  With an AJAX request, JavaScript is the one making the call to the Server. When the response returns from the Server, it will be handled by JavaScript. It will NOT be displayed by the browser.

                  So, you can use JavaScript to send a request to a web server for an image, an HTML file, a text file, an XML file, or a JSON file, amoung other types.

                  When the file comes back to the browser, JavaScript will be notified and you will have a function that is triggered. Your function can display the contents, or partial-contents of your returned file.

                  This is how websites like Google Maps can update the images and content on a web page WITHOUT having to reload the page. Google Maps' implementation of AJAX technology is what allowed them to create a much better user experience and how they effectively robbed Yahoo! MapQuest of all their users.

                   

                   

                   

                   

                  XMLHttpRequest Object (OLD AJAX Standard)

                  When Microsoft originally introduced the technology behind AJAX, back with IE 5.5, they were using a proprietary ActiveX control. The W3C created a standardized Object to be used when making AJAX calls.

                  var xhr = new XMLHttpRequest( );

                  However, it took nearly ten years for Microsoft to transition from using their proprietary version to the open standard method.

                  Currently all browsers support this standard method. This is great for writing cross-browser compatible code. However, in recent years a new replacement for XMLHttpRequest has appeared called the Fetch API. The Fetch API has quickly gained cross-browser support and is a much more flexible interface to use in making AJAX requests. In our program we will be using the Fetch API for nearly all of our AJAX work. 

                  However, nearly all the AJAX code currently in production uses this older standard version. For that reason, we must know how to work with it.

                  var xhr = new XMLHttpRequest();
                  xhr.open('GET', 'data.json', true);
                  xhr.addEventListener('load', function(ev){
                    switch(ev.status){
                      case 200:
                      case 302:
                        //handle a good response
                        var data = JSON.parse( ev.responseText );
                        //call some function to do something with the JSON data
                      case 404:
                        //handle a 404 error gracefully
                      default:
                        //handle all other errors
                    }
                  });
                  xhr.addEventListener('error', function(err){
                    //handle any error that has to do with network failure
                  });
                  xhr.send(null);

                   

                  Fetch API (NEW AJAX Standard)

                  As previously mentioned, we will be using the Fetch API instead of the XMLHttpRequest object to make all of our AJAX calls.

                  The primary difference between the two approaches is that the Fetch API uses the new ES6 Promises feature to make the requests and handle the responses. The XMLHttpRequest object has an open( ) method to set up the request and a send( ) method to actually send the request to the server. XMLHttpRequest uses Event Listeners to wait for load, readystatechange, error, or progress events.

                  There is a lot of boilerplate code for the XMLHttpRequest objects.

                  Promises

                  A basic Promise looks like this:

                  myPromise( )
                    .then(func1)
                    .then(func2)
                    .then(func3)
                    .catch(errorFunc);

                  The way a Promise works is by chaining together a series of functions to be called in order.

                  1. You call the initial Promise method to start the process.

                  2. If that succeeds then it will call whatever function you put inside the then( ) method.

                  3. You can chain together as many then( ) methods as you want.

                  4. Each then function  will pass it's return value to the next then( ) method function.

                  5. If there is a failure during ANY step then the catch( ) method function at the end of the chain gets called.

                  You can put the name of the function inside the then( ) method parentheses or you can put an anonymous function.

                  myPromise( )
                    .then(function(val){ 
                      //do something with val
                      return otherVal;
                    })
                    .then( function(otherval){ 
                      //do something with this new value
                      //otherval is the return value from the first then( ) function
                    })
                    .catch( function(err){ 
                      //handle the error passed in variable err
                    });

                  Fetch API

                  As mentioned above, the Fetch API uses Promises. In fact, the primary fetch( ) method is a Promise. The methods that you use to convert your Server response into a JSON object or String or Image are also Promises.

                  fetch( url )
                    .then( function(response){ 
                      return response.json();
                    })
                    .then( function(data){
                      //do something with data, which is your JSON data from the url.
                    })
                    .catch( function(err){
                      console.log("Error");
                    });

                   

                  Here is a CodePen that demonstrates using fetch to retrieve a JSON file from a web server.

                   

                  And another CodePen that demonstrates using Fetch to retrieve some JSON data which is being pulled from another CodePen - http://codepen.io/mad-d/pen/mErbpM.js? (Links to an external site.) 

                   

                  A couple great starter tutorials on using Fetch:

                  https://davidwalsh.name/fetch (Links to an external site.) 

                  https://developers.google.com/web/updates/2015/03/introduction-to-fetch (Links to an external site.)

                   

                  Request, Header, Body, USVString, Response Objects

                  The process of requesting files from a Server can seem very simple or very complex. It really comes down to how many properties and parameters you want to deal with. The fetch API can be a very compact and simple tool but it allows for a lot of complexity in dealing with any situation that is required.

                  Every fetch( ) consists of sending a Request to the Server and waiting for a Response.

                  Both the Request and Response contain Headers and a Body.

                  The Headers contain all the settings and the Body contains the data or the file which is being sent either from the browser to the Server or from the Server to the browser.

                  The Request can contain Request properties, Headers, and a Body.

                  The Response can contain Response properties, Headers, and a Body.

                  Request Object

                  When calling the fetch( ) method we can either pass in a USVString or a Request Object.

                  To create a Request Object we would use the new Request( ) constructor. The most basic example, using all default properties is:

                  let req = new Request( url );

                  You can also optionally add an init object with values for the various properties of the Request.

                  let req = new Request( url, {method:'POST', body: myFormData});

                  The properties of the Request can include:

                  method:  'GET', 'POST', or 'HEAD'

                  headers: a Headers object

                  mode: 'cors' or 'no-cors'  (Cross-Origin Resource Sharing), or 'same-origin'.

                  cache:  'default', 'no-store', 'reload', 'no-cache', or 'force-cache' - the cache mode to use for the request.

                  body: The data to be sent with a request that is using method: 'POST'. This property can be a Blob, a USVString, a FormData object, or a URLSearchParams object.

                  MDN reference - https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Request (Links to an external site.) 

                  URLSearchParams - https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/URLSearchParams (Links to an external site.) 

                  FormData - https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/FormData (Links to an external site.) 

                  Header Object

                  The Header Object represents all the HTTP headers in both the Request and the Response.

                  It can be passed as a value to the Request init property:

                  let myHeaders = new Header();
                  myHeaders.append('Content-Type', 'image/jpeg');
                  let url = 'someImage.jpg';
                  let req = new Request( url, {headers: myHeaders } );

                  It is important to keep in mind that while you can create your own headers, there is a list of headers which are read-only and the browsers will not allow you to set values for them.

                  List of Forbidden Header names - https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Glossary/Forbidden_header_name (Links to an external site.) 

                  MDN reference - https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Headers (Links to an external site.) 

                  Body Object

                  The Body is the container for the data that is either passed to a Server-Side page or the file that gets returned to the Browser.

                  Body.json();  //used to extract the JSON representation from a JSON file in the response

                  Body.text(); //used to extract the string version of an XML, HTML, or other text file.

                  Body.blob();  //used to extract the image from the response body

                  Body.formData( ); //will return a FormData representation of the Body 

                  MDN reference - https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Body (Links to an external site.) 

                  USVString

                  A Unicode Scalar Value String is effectively a URL. This is one option of what you would pass to the fetch( ) method.

                  MDN reference - https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/USVString (Links to an external site.) 

                  Response Object

                  The last part of the fetch process is handling the Response. Just like the Request, it can contain Headers as well as the Body.

                  When you call the fetch method, the first then( ) function will receive the Request object as it's only parameter. From that function you can call the json( ), blob( ), or text( ) method to extract the desired data from the Response Body.

                  fetch( url )
                  .then( function( resp ){ 
                    //extract the JSON Object from the returned file
                    return resp.json( );
                  }).then( function( data ){ 
                    //the variable data will contain the JSON data from the returned file.
                  }).catch( function(err){ 
                    //handle any errors
                  });

                  In the example, above, the variable resp is a Response object. Here are the methods that you would call in that first then( ) function.

                  Response.json( ); //if your returned file was a .json file.

                  Response.text( );  //if you were expecting HTML, XML, text, or CSV

                  Response.blob( );  //if you were expecting a binary file like an image, video, or audio.

                  Response.formData( ); //in the rare case when you get FormValue pairs back from the Server

                  MDN reference - https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Response (Links to an external site.) 

                  Installing MAMP

                  In order to run AJAX calls properly in all browsers we need to use a web server.

                  Some browsers, most notably Chrome, have very restrictive security settings around AJAX usage. We can't be using a page over file:/// and request a web page from http://  (Links to an external site.) or https://  (Links to an external site.)

                  So, we need to have a web server running on our computer or we need to use an external web server - like our Edumedia server. The only downside to an external web server is the fact that you have to use FTP to upload files to test them and every time you make a change to a file you need to upload it again.

                   

                  The solution is to install a web server on your own computer. There are many different ones.

                  OSX

                  MAMP:  https://www.mamp.info/en/ (Links to an external site.) 

                  XAMPP: https://www.apachefriends.org/download.html (Links to an external site.) 

                  Windows

                  WAMP: http://www.wampserver.com/en/ (Links to an external site.) 

                  XAMPP: https://www.apachefriends.org/download.html (Links to an external site.) 

                  MAMP: https://www.mamp.info/en/ (Links to an external site.) 

                   

                  After you download and install the server you will actually have three things:

                  1. Apache (the web server)

                  2. MySQL (a database)

                  3. PHP (the PHP program for server-side programming)

                   

                  Web servers all have a single root folder that is used to store all your websites. The name and location of this folder varies from one server package to the next.

                  In MAD9111 you should have already installed MAMP. Here are the default locations of the root web server.

                  OSX

                  /Applications/MAMP/htdocs/

                  Windows

                  C:\MAMP\htdocs\

                  Description

                  Build a mobile-first responsive web app that will provide the user with the ability to generate random lottery numbers.

                  The web app will have two screens. The first screen will contain an HTML form that lets the user choose how many numbers they want to generate plus the range for each of the numbers (min and max). The second screen will display the numbers which are returned from the server-side api.

                  When the user clicks the submit button on the first screen, you must take the information that the user has entered and send it via an AJAX call to the PHP link provided below.

                  Here are a couple screenshots of a very basic layout of the two screens. These show only a vertical layout. Your layout should change as the screen becomes wider.

                    

                  Here is a sample starter file for the HTML - index.html. You can use this HTML or create your own.

                   

                  Design

                  For the Responsive part - just add a series of media queries that change the display size & font-size of your content so it occupies a more appropriate amount of the screen. We want to fill most of the screen at any resolution.

                   

                  Restrictions

                  You must use the fetch( ) method to make your AJAX call.

                   

                  References

                  The PHP link for the API - https://griffis.edumedia.ca/mad9014/lotto/nums.php (Links to an external site.) 

                  The AJAX call should be made via POST.

                  It requires two parameters called "digits" and "max". The parameters should be saved in a FormData object OR a URLSearchParams object OR just a String appended as the query string. to be transmitted. An example URL would be https://griffis.edumedia.ca/mad9014/lotto/nums.php?digits=4&max=19 (Links to an external site.) 

                  Submission

                  FTP your completed HTML, CSS, images, and JS to the edumedia server.

                  Eg: http://adcd0001.edumedia.ca/mad9014/lotto/index.html (Links to an external site.)

                  Submit the URL of your home page.

                   

                  Bonus Challenges

Once, you have your number set, check for duplicates. If there are any duplicates, then make a new fetch call which will request a new set of numbers from the server.

                  Week 8 Summary

                   

                  Learning Objective: By the end of this week, students will have demonstrated the following: How to work with AJAX and a variety of JavaScript JSON APIs.

                  • Work on the AJAX Lotto assignment

                  • Lectures about programming concepts
                  • Lectures and practice with JavaScript to make AJAX calls

                    FormData Object & URLSearchParams

                    When making AJAX calls to an API, we often need to send additional data as part of the request. The data we send can take many forms, including querystrings or form data.

                    QueryStrings can always be passed as part of the URL and just handled as a String, but they can also be stored inside a URLSearchParams object. Data that you gather can also be packaged inside a FormData object. 

                    When you want to send data to your API call packaged in either a URLSearchParams object or a FormData object then we MUST use the POST method. If you keep the querystring as a String and just part of the URL then we can use the GET method or the POST method.

                    Both the FormData object and the URLSearchParams object store data in a similar way: as name - value pairs.

                    Let's start with a name and email address pulled from a web form.

                    let name = document.getElementById("name").value;
                    let email = document.getElementById("email").value;

                    Then we store the data in one of the following ways.

                    In a FormData object:

                    let form = new FormData();
                    form.append("name", name);
                    form.append("email", email);

                    OR In a URLSearchParams object:

                    let query = new URLSearchParams();
                    query.append("name", name);
                    query.append("email", email);

                    Then we place the data in a Request object and send it with our fetch call:

                    let url = "http://www.example.com/";
                    let req = new Request(url, {
                        method: "POST",
                        body: form
                    });

                    fetch(req)
                      .then( function(response){
                        return response.json();
                      })
                      .then( data ){
                        //data is our JSON object back from our request
                      });

                     

                    FormData Object & URLSearchParams

                    QueryStrings can always be passed as part of the URL and just handled as a String, but they can also be stored inside a URLSearchParams object. Data that you gather can also be packaged inside a FormData object.

                      .then( function(response){

                      .then( data ){
                        //data is our JSON object back from our request
                      });

                     

                    JSONPlaceholder

                    Ever want to test your JavaScript AJAX code without having to build the server-side part first?

                    http://jsonplaceholder.typicode.com/ (Links to an external site.)

                    This is a free service for generating sample JSON data.

                    Depending on the number of data points you want returned you can choose from the following possible URLs

                    http://jsonplaceholder.typicode.com/posts (Links to an external site.) - 100 items

                    http://jsonplaceholder.typicode.com/comments (Links to an external site.) - 500 items

                    http://jsonplaceholder.typicode.com/albums (Links to an external site.) - 100 items

                    http://jsonplaceholder.typicode.com/photos (Links to an external site.) - 5000 items

                    http://jsonplaceholder.typicode.com/todos (Links to an external site.) - 200 items

                    http://jsonplaceholder.typicode.com/users (Links to an external site.) - 10 items

                     

                    Each URL provides a different type of data.

                    You can use either GET or POST with your requests.

                     

                     

                    DarkSky.net API

                    DarkSky (formerly forecast.io) is a great weather data API. To use it you need to register as a developer with the website.

                    https://darksky.net/dev/register (Links to an external site.) - register here.

                    Once you have registered then you will be able to make up to 1000 calls per day to the API for free.

                    After logging in, you will see a page that looks like this. The important thing on this page is the Secret Key. This image shows an old version of my key. You will get a unique key that is valid for your account. You will need that key for every call you make to the API.

                     

                    A basic call to the API consists of a URL with the endpoint for the API, your secret key, and a latitude and longitude.

                    Eg: https://api.darksky.net/forecast/<your secret key here >/37.8267,-122.4233 

                    This page has an example of the JSON response you get back. - https://darksky.net/dev/docs/forecast (Links to an external site.)

                    The key, latitude, and longitude are the required parameters.

                    There are also several optional parameters. All the optional parameters must be added as query string parameters.

                    https://api.darksky.net/forecast/<your secret key here >/37.8267,-122.4233?units=ca&lang=de

                    This example has set the language as German (de - Deutsch) and the units for reporting the data as Canadian (metric). 

                    Another optional parameter is "excludes". It is used to remove some of the blocks from the response, which reduces the size of the returned data and speeds things up and makes it easier to cache results.

                     

                    Website - https://darksky.net/45.4207,-75.7023 (Links to an external site.)

                    Developer reference - https://darksky.net/dev/ (Links to an external site.)

                    API endpoint - https://api.darksky.net/ (Links to an external site.) (needs API key to work)

                    Important Notes

                    Currently, DarkSky does NOT allow CORS requests from the browser. 

                    You can place the URL for the call you want to make in the location bar of your browser to view the data.

                    However, if you want to get the data to your JavaScript then you need to 

                    a) Use a CURL call from a PHP page to pass the data from DarkSky back to your JavaScript. The PHP CURL call must reside on the same server as your JavaScript.

                    b) Make a JSONP (JSON with Padding) call to return the data to your script via the HTML page.

                     

                    Numeric or Multi-dimensional Sorting

                    When you want to sort a simple Array it is not a difficult task, we just use the sort( ) method.

                    let arr = ["Charlie", "Aaron", "Michael", "Eric"];
                    let sortedArray = arr.sort( );

                    When the array stores more complex data, like Objects or other Arrays, then sorting becomes a bit more complex. The other drawback to the standard sort function is that it sorts everything as if it were Strings only. It uses the String version of the numbers to sort them. This means that if you were to sort the numbers 1 to 12, then this is the result of the sort.

                    1, 10, 11, 12, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9

                    Likely not what you wanted.

                    Thankfully, the sort method allows us to provide our own custom sorting function. 

                    Here is the MDN reference - https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/sort (Links to an external site.)

                    Sorting Numbers

                    To sort numbers we need to use the custom function and make it compare the numerical values.

                    The custom function will need to accept two parameters. The parameters that get passed in are the values from the array. The values to be compared will be continually be passed in until the array is sorted.

                    If compareFunction(a, b) is less than 0, sort a to a lower index than b, i.e. a comes first.

                    If compareFunction(a, b) returns 0, leave a and b unchanged with respect to each other, but sorted with respect to all different elements. Note: the ECMAscript standard does not guarantee this behaviour, and thus not all browsers (e.g. Mozilla versions dating back to at least 2003) respect this.

                    If compareFunction(a, b) is greater than 0, sort b to a lower index than a.

                    compareFunction(a, b) must always return the same value when given a specific pair of elements a and b as its two arguments. If inconsistent results are returned then the sort order is undefined.

                    Here is the code version of these rules:

                    function compare(a, b) {
  if (a is less than b by some ordering criterion) {
    return -1;
  }
  if (a is greater than b by the ordering criterion) {
    return 1;
  }
  // a must be equal to b
  return 0;
}

                    A simple easy way to create that function for comparing numbers is just to subtract one number from the other and return the result.

                    function compare(a, b){
                      return a - b;
                    }

                     

                    Sorting Complex Objects

                    When it come to sorting more complex items like Objects or multi-dimensional (nested) arrays then we need to write a function that will look at those values and select the part or parts you are using to sort them.

                    Take this following example. We want to sort the array of students by their names. However, the array is made up of Objects, and the names are stored inside a name property inside each object. To do the sort we need to use the custom function and target the name property inside of each.

                    let students = [
                        {"name": "Alex", "id": "040111222" },
                        {"name": "Devon", "id": "040222333" },
                        {"name": "Riley", "id": "040333444" },
                        {"name": "Cara", "id": "040555666" },
                        {"name": "Cole", "id": "040666777" },
                        {"name": "Bree", "id": "040777888" } ];
                    students.sort( function(a, b){
                      let nameA = a.name.toUpperCase();
                      let nameB = b.name.toUpperCase();
                      if( nameA < nameB ){
                        return -1;
                      }
                      if( nameA > nameB ){
                        return 1;
                      }
                      return 0;
                    }); 

                    Now the function will be able to use the return values to sort the students array.

                     

                    CORS

                    CORS stands for Cross-Origin Resource Sharing. It refers to the process by which the browser can make HTTP Requests to load an HTML file from one domain and then other things like images, fonts, stylesheets, and scripts from different domains.

                    If the browser is making the request based on what it read in an HTML or CSS file then this can be done freely.

                    If the cross-domain request is coming from some JavaScript code then there are restrictions in place.

                    JavaScript can use the Fetch API or XMLHttpRequest objects to make requests for resources like XML, JSON, text, images, stylesheets, fonts, videos, audio files, etc. However, we have to follow a restrictive list of rules to be able to make those requests.

                    Headers

                    When you configure the fetch( ) call with the Request and Headers objects you can only use the following:

                    Method can only be GET, HEAD, or POST

                    The only headers that can be set are: Accept, Content-Type, Accept-Language, and Content-Language. No other headers can be altered for a CORS request.

                    Accept tells the server what types of files you are willing to accept as a response. Content-type tells the server what type of file you are sending. The only three values allowed for Content-Type are text/plain, multipart/form-data, or x-www-form-urlencoded.

                    Mode

                    When using the Fetch API we can set the CORS mode for the request. Basically we are going to tell the server that we do or do not want to make a cross-domain request.

                    Inside our Request options we define the mode like this:

                    let options = {
                        method: "GET",
                        mode: "cors"
                    }

                    The mode can be "cors", "same-origin", or "no-cors". If we set it to "cors" then we are telling the browser to look for the proper permissions to come back from the remote webserver telling us that CORS is allowed. If we set it to "same-origin" then we are telling the browser that it should prevent the JavaScript from making calls to any domain except the one where the HTML came from. "no-cors" tries to make an opaque attempt to get external sources but does not currently work within the global scope of the page.

                    Behind the Scenes

                    When you make a CORS AJAX call from your JavaScript code there are actually two requests being made. An initial request called a pre-flight request gets sent from the browser to the server. This request includes a header providing the domain from which the request is being made. 

                    For the communication between the server and the browser to finish properly, the server needs to respond to the initial preflight request with a Response that includes a header called Access-Control-Allow-Origin. The value for this header must match exactly your URL or be set to a wildcard.

                    With Apache, we can create a settings file called .htaccess and inside that file add this line:

                    Header set Access-Control-Allow-Origin "*"

                    This will create the required header to allow for cross origin requests.

                    The .htaccess file must be in the folder or a parent folder for the resource being requested.

                     

                    What Gets Restricted

                    There are actually quite a few things that can get restricted when requesting resources over CORS. For our immediate purposes, it is important to note that a webpage making a request from edumedia.ca to darksky.net would not be allowed to use the JSON data.

                    If you set the mode to "same-origin" or "no-cors" then the request would be entirely rejected.

                    If you set the mode to "cors" then the request would be sent and the JSON data returned but we would not be allowed to use the data in our JavaScript. 

                    MDN CORS reference - https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Access_control_CORS (Links to an external site.)  

                     

                    Forecast Web App

                    Re-submit Assignment
                    • Due Nov 9 by 11:59pm
                    • Points 40
                    • Submitting a website url

                    This assignment is to create a Single Page Web App all about todays weather. It will always display the weather for the next 24 hours starting at the current time. All the weather data is coming from https://darksky.net/dev/ You will need to register with the site for a developer key so you can access the weather data via AJAX. The API Endpoint will be https://api.darksky.net/ 

                    You can put the URL for your call directly into your browser location bar to see what you get back.

                    Unfortunately, due to CORS restrictions we cannot make calls to darksky.net directly from edumedia.ca. Read this page for more details - CORS

                    So, the solution is to have some server-side code on edumedia.ca that IS allowed to request data from darksky.net. Here is the PHP code that you can place in your folder on Edumedia. - forecast.php

                    NEW VERSION of forecast.php that allows users to upload a latlng parameter via querystring or FormData.

                    Here is a copy of the .htaccess file that you can place in your assignment folder - ht.access. You will have to rename this file. Because of security restrictions we cannot upload files to Canvas whose name starts with a period.

                    You will make your fetch call to THAT PHP page and it will return the data from darksky to you. For the PHP code to work properly, you must edit the PHP file in two places.

                    1. Add your secret API key on line 4.

                    2. Add the proper value for the units on line 10 in order to ensure that we get metric values.

                    Layout

                    The layout is a responsive one which will display different amounts of data in a different configuration depending on the screen dimensions. Here are some sample screenshots showing the responsive page during a rainy day.

                      

                    As you can see, the number of columns/rows changes depending on the space available on the screen. The whole screen is taken up by the information and separated into easily understood chunks.

                    Your interface does NOT have to look exactly like this one.

                    Yours MUST be responsive. It MUST use background colours and icons to represent the weather. It MUST show at least the time and the temperature.

                    The key to showing the weather at different times is to use your JavaScript to create a weather <div> for every hour. THEN use CSS to control which <div>s appear within the different media queries.

                    If you have a display that only shows 4 different times during the day, then hide the other 20 in your CSS media query using display:none; and display:block;.

                    Fonts

                    You can use any SANS SERIF font you want for this. Create ONE font stack and use it for everything except the icons. You may use a Google font, as long as it is a sans-serif one, and as long as you create a proper font-stack.

                    Icons

                    There is a great set of weather icons available for free here - http://erikflowers.github.io/weather-icons

                    The icons are actually a font. Include the CSS file in your HTML. Add the CSS file to your CSS folder. Add a folder called fonts to your project and put the icon font files in that folder.

                    To use the icons create HTML like this:

                    <i class="wi wi-day-sunny"></i>

                    The italic tag, which doesn't get used for anything since being replaced by the <em> tag is a great container for the icon. Each icon is just a single letter shown in the weather icon font. The provided CSS will look for the class wi to set the font-family and will then look for the classes like wi-day-sunny to decide which icon to display.

                    The DarkSky API will return a description of the weather to be used for icons. the property in the JSON is actually called "icon".

                    When creating your HTML for the weather, take the icon name from the JSON and then prepend "wi-day-" in front of the icon name. 

                    Alternate sets of icons are available here - http://darkskyapp.github.io/skycons/ and here - http://adamwhitcroft.com/climacons/. Feel free to use any of the three sets. Just remember to adjust your CSS and JS to work with the different sets.

                     

                    Colours

                    In your CSS to set the background colours, use the "icon" property from the JSON as a class on your <div> too.

                    Here are the possible values for the icon ( from this page https://darksky.net/dev/docs/response )

                    clear-day, clear-night, rain, snow, sleet, wind, fog, cloudy, partly-cloudy-day, or partly-cloudy-night

                    If you want, you can create a CSS selector for each or just create a selector that deals with variations, like this:

                    div[class*="clear"]{
                        background-color: gold;
                    } 

                    The attribute selector above uses a wildcard character (asterix) to create a selector that looks for any <div> that has a class attribute which contains "clear" somewhere in the name. 

                    Units

                    The weather data must all be in metric.

                    JSONP

                    JSONP stands for JSON with Padding. It is an alternate way to get around CORS issues. Server-side pass throughs are a common solution, JSONP is the other solution.

                    CORS restricts calls made via XMLHttpRequest( ) and fetch( ). However, we can load any script we want through an HTML <script> tag. 

                    <script src="app.js"></script>
                    <!-- <script src="http://www.example.com/data.js"></script> -->
                    <script src="http://www.example.com/data.js?callback=myfunc"></script>

                    The first script tag is your local javascript file. The second is a normal request for a JavaScript file. The third one is requesting the same JavaScript file but also includes a querystring parameter. The third one is what a JSONP request looks like. We don't need the commented one.

                    The server that hosts the javascript must support JSONP. There must be some server-side code that alters the contents of the JavaScript file. If the original version of the JavaScript file looked like this

                    {"pets": [ 
                      {"name":"Bob", "age": 2},
                      {"name":"Jesse", "age": 4},
                      {"name":"Woody", "age": 14}]};

                    Then the JSONP version could look like this:

                    myfunc( 
  {"pets": [ 
                      {"name":"Bob", "age": 2},
                      {"name":"Jesse", "age": 4},
                      {"name":"Woody", "age": 14}]};
));

                    The "data" which comprised the whole file is now wrapped inside a call to a function called myfunc. The data becomes a parameter being passed to the function.

                    In your other JavaScript file, the one you created in your project, you will have a function called myfunc.

                    function myfunc( data ){
                      //'data' is now the data that came from the external source
                    }

                     

                    So, we pass the name of our function as a querystring parameter to the external URL. The URL might point to a file with a .js extension, a .php extension, or no extension. The important thing is that what gets returned is JavaScript. That JavaScript will be formatted as a bunch of JSON data, WRAPPED in a function call. 

                    In our own JavaScript code we create the function with the same name that we pass as a querystring parameter. Our function will be called by the JavaScript file that comes back from the external server. Our function runs and accepts all that external data as its' input parameter.

                     

                    Restrictions

                    The external data source must have code that accepts the request including the querystring parameter. The external course will have a specific name for the querystring parameter, although "callback" is a common one.

                    We must have a function in our code that matches the name of the one that we send in the querystring.

                      localStorage and sessionStorage

                      localStorage and sessionStorage are two methods that we can use to save data locally in the user's browser. If you want to save a list of names, a game highscore, the last video watched and the time stopped in that video, then localStorage is an ideal method to save this information.

                      When the browser saves this information, it also remembers what domain and folder it was saved from. This way the information can be restricted and other websites will not be able to read it.

                      If I am on www.example.com (Links to an external site.) and I save some information in localStorage, then navigate to www.algonquincollege.com (Links to an external site.), the information from www.example.com (Links to an external site.) will NOT be accessible by any JavaScript code on www.algonquincollege.com (Links to an external site.).

                      SessionStorage and localStorage work the same way. The difference between them is that sessionStorage is deleted when you close your browser.

                       

                      Putting Data into localStorage

                      All the data that you put into localStorage will be the String equivalent of the data.

                      Each thing that you want to save will need to have a key to identify it.

                      localStorage.setItem(key, value);       //using variables
                      localStorage.setItem('name', 'Steve');  //using strings
                      localStorage.setItem("names", '["Rick","Morty"]' );     //saving an Array as a String

                      Every key needs to be unique.

                       

                      Retrieving Data from localStorage

                      When you want to retrieve that information we need to know the key.

                      let name = localStorage.getItem('name');      //The string Steve
                      let names = localStorage.getItem('names');    //this will be a String, not an array

                      See below about how to use the JSON object to convert that String into a real Array.

                      To remove a single item from localStorage we would use the removeItem( ) method. To remove ALL the information from localStorage we would use the clear( ) method.

                      localStorage.removeItem('name');      //remove the item with the key 'name'
                      localStorage.clear( );                //remove ALL the items

                      We can also check to see if a key already exists.

                      if( localStorage.getItem('booya') ){
                        //that key exists
                      }else{
                        //nothing with that key exists
                      }

                       

                      JSON Again

                      All the data that you put into localStorage will be a string. However, the most efficient use of that string is to use a JSON string. When we pull the string out of localStorage we will convert it into a JSON object. If you make a change to the JSON data and then want to put it back into localStorage we convert the JSON object back into a String.

                      let jsonData = JSON.parse( myStringOfJsonData );

                      let stringVersion = JSON.stringify( jsonData );

                       

                      Codepen sample showing how you can save a list of names in localStorage, edit the list, display the list, etc.

                      http://codepen.io/mad-d/pen/qajOQj?editors=1010 (Links to an external site.)  

                       

                      bitwise operators

                       The Bitwise operators allow us to use JavaScript and work with numbers at the binary level.

                      The Bitwise AND operator

                      & - binary AND operator

                      The binary & operator is used to AND two numbers at the binary level

                        11001010 
                      & 00001111  //the result of this is 00001010

                       For each bit we compare the matching positions if both are a 1 then the result in that position is 1.

                      The Bitwise Shift Operators

                      Sometimes we want to trim off the last few digits of a binary number or we want to add some more digits. The shift operators let us do that. The best example of this is when we want to extract the red, green, and blue parts of a colour value.

                      Hex colours are made up of three values 00-FF, 00-FF, and 00-FF. Each one is a number between 0 and 255. 

                      In binary, 255 is 11111111. That is 8 ones. So, for each colour there are 8 bits. The colour white is (255, 255, 255) or #FFFFFF.

                      In binary white would be 11111111 11111111 11111111. That is why Jpegs are called 24 bit images. Each pixel is a colour made up of 24 bits. Black would be represented by 24 zeroes - 00000000 00000000 00000000.

                      If you write 24 ones as a decimal number it is 2 to the power of 24 or 16,777,216.

                      A random colour would be a value between 0 and 16,777,216.

                      So, if we had the random number 1,654,344, in binary that would be 00011001 00111110 01001000. The first 8 bits represent the red colour, the middle 8 bits are the green value, and the last 8 bits are the blue value.

                      If you want to extract those three parts of the one colour, we will use the shift operator.

                      For the red colour, we will shift the bits 16 places to the right. Basically, we are stripping off the rightmost 16 bits. Leaving us only the first 8 bits 00011001. In decimal, that would be - 25.

                      For the blue colour, we will use the AND operator. We AND the whole number with 255 (or 11111111). This will make the left most 16 bits zero. Only the 8 right most bits could possibly line up with our 255. The result will be 01001000 or 72.

                      For the green colour we need to do both things - shift over 8 bits and then AND the right most 8 bits with 11111111 (255). The green portion 00111110 is 62.

                      So, the RGB version of 00011001 00111110 01001000 is rgb(25, 62, 72).
