                      geolocation API

                      Geolocation in the browser runs through two methods

                      navigator.geolocation.getCurrentPosition( successCallback, failCallback, options);
                      navigator.geolocation.watchPosition( successCallback, failCallback, options);

                      The two functions are the same except that getCurrentPosition runs once and watchPosition runs repeatedly. If you want to stop the watchPosition method running then we call:

                      navigator.geolocation.clearWatch();

                      Both methods accept a success callback function and a failure callback function. The success function will be passed a position object. The failure callback will be passed a position error object. See the code below for examples.

                      Position reference - https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Position (Links to an external site.) 

                      PositionError reference - https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/PositionError (Links to an external site.) 

                      The third parameter is the options object.

                      let options = {
                        enableHighAccuracy: true,
                        timeout: 5000,
                        maximumAge: 0
                      }

                      more details on the options - https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/PositionOptions (Links to an external site.)  

                       

                       

                      https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Geolocation (Links to an external site.)

                       

                      Date methods

                      Dates in JavaScript are a special type of Object. They are not just Strings.

                      They have a long list of methods that we can use to set or retrieve a date value or a portion of the date. To create a Date object we need to use the new constructor.

                      let today = new Date();
                      let dt1 = new Date('28/9/2016 14:30:00.000');
                      let dt2 = new Date(2016, 9, 28, 14, 30, 0);

                      The first line above will create a new Date object and it will fill it with the current date and time from the computer that is running the script.

                      The second line creates a new Date object and sets a specific date and time. We pass in a String with a valid date and time. The values for day, month, year, hour, minutes, seconds, and milliseconds would be set inside our Date object. The String that is passed in must be a date string that would be recognized by the Date.parse( ) method. See here for examples - https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Date/parse#Examples (Links to an external site.) 

                      The third line accepts up to seven arguments for the parts of the Date. The last argument is the milliseconds. dt2 will contain the same date as dt1 from the example code.

                       

                      Setting Date Values

                      If you want to update any part of the date or time then we use one of the following methods.

                      today.setHours(12);         // from 0-23. OR  setHours(hour, mins, seconds, milliseconds)
                      today.setMinutes(3);        // from 0-59. OR setMinutes(mins, seconds, milliseconds)
                      today.setSeconds(50);       // from 0 - 59  OR setSeconds(seconds, milliseconds)
                      today.setMilliseconds(123); // from 0 - 999
                      today.setFullYear(2044);
                      today.setMonth(0);          //value from 0 - 11 (like an array) OR setMonth( month, day)
                      today.setDate();            //value from 1 - 31  invalid dates will move forward to a valid one

                      Date.UTC(y, m, d, hr, min, sec, ms);  //creates a date object and returns the timestamp
                                                            //equivalent of the date

                       

                      Retrieving Date Values

                      If you want to retrieve any part of the date or time then you can use the matching "get" methods. Start with using your Date variable and then call the method on the variable

                      today.getHours();
                      today.getMinutes();
                      today.getSeconds();
                      today.getMilliseconds();
                      today.getFullYear();
                      today.getMonth();        // value from 0 - 11
                      today.getDate();         // value from 1 - 31
                      today.getDay();          //day of week Sunday (0) - Saturday (6)

                      Date.now();       //Using the Date object, call now( ) to get a timestamp
                                        //which is the number of milliseconds since the start of the UNIX Epoch
                                        //midnight January 1, 1970

                       

                      Outputting Dates

                      There are many methods for outputting the date object's value. Here is a list of the various methods.

                      today.toDateString(); //returns the date portion in human readable format
                      today.toTimeString(); //returns the time portion in human readable format

                       https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Date/toDateString (Links to an external site.)

                      https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Date/toTimeString (Links to an external site.) 

                      today.toISOString();  //returns a string in simplified extended ISO format

                       https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Date/toISOString (Links to an external site.)

                      today.toJSON();   //converts the date to a string intended to be used in JSON

                      https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Date/toJSON (Links to an external site.) 

                      today.toLocaleDateString('en-CA');  //returns a string representation based on the 
                                                          //computer's locale settings or provided locale
                      today.toLocaleString('en-GB');      //same thing effectively
                      today.toLocaleString('en-US');

                      https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Date/toLocaleDateString (Links to an external site.)

                      https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Date/toLocaleString (Links to an external site.)

                      today.toUTCString();  //returns the date string using UTC time zone

                      https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Date/toUTCString (Links to an external site.) 

                       

                      Working With Months

                      In the JavaScript Date object, months are stored as a number between 0 and 11. 

                      If you want to see or use the name of the month then you need to create your own array of the month names and use the Date object month as the index for that array.

                      let months = ['Jan','Feb','Mar','Apr','May','Jun','Jul','Sep','Oct','Nov','Dec'];
                      let today = new Date();
                      console.log('Current month is:', months[ today.getMonths() ] );

                       

                      Converting to Timestamps (unary)

                      The unary operator is an easy way to convert a date into its numeric timestamp.

                      let timestamp = +today;        //convert the value in the date to a timestamp
                      let timestamp = +new Date();   //convert the current computer time to a timestamp

                       

                      The Date object reference page:

                      https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Date (Links to an external site.)

                       

                      Moment.JS Library

                      If you are building something that works with a lot of dates or times then it can help to have a JavaScript library that you can use. MomentJS is a great JS library http://momentjs.com/ (Links to an external site.) for formatting and validating dates.

                       

                       

                      JavaScript Timers

                      Timeouts 

                       When you want to run a function after a specific time delay then setTimeout is the built-in function to accomplish this.

                      setTimeout( myFunc, 3000);  //call the function myFunc after 3000ms
                      setTimeout( function(){ alert('hi'); }, 2500);  //run the anonymous function after 2500ms
                      setTimeout( 'myFunc()', 1000);     //call the function myFunc after 1 second
                      window.setTimeout( myFunc, 300);   //same as first example

                       

                      Intervals

                      When you want to run something repeatedly after a set time, for example, once every ten seconds, then setInterval is the function to call. 

                      Timers running on intervals can be stopped if you call the clearInterval( ) method. Just make sure that you keep a reference to the interval.

                      let intervalId = setInterval( myFunc, 3000);
                      //keep calling myFunc every 3 seconds 
                      ....
                      //use the intervalId to stop the interval calls running
                      clearInterval( intervalId );

                       

                      Recursive Timeouts

                      Another way to approach timed intervals is with a recursive call to the setTimeout function. Inside the function that runs following your setTimeout, you make another call to the same function. The process repeats itself.

                      The difference with the recursive calls is that it allows us to change the amount of time between the calls or stop it after any call. 

                      We can use this method to create ever shorter time spans between callbacks or random times between callbacks.

                       

                      Here is a CodePen that shows the shrinking timeout. Click the Div to start the countdown. Each time the function runs, the delay between calls is reduced by 7%. When the delay is less than 15 milliseconds it will cease to callback the function. 

                       

                      Creating Modal Windows with JavaScript

                      A Modal Window is like a pop-up interface that the user must interact with before returning to the main page. There are two key parts when creating Modal Windows in the browser. First you need to create an overlay and second you create the div that will appear on top of the overlay as the modal window.

                      Creating the Overlay

                      The overlay is mostly CSS. With JavaScript we will be toggling the value of display between none and block.

                      The HTML:

                      <div class="overlay"></div>

                      The CSS:

                      .overlay{
                        display:none;
                        position: fixed;
                        z-index: 100;
                        top: 0;
                        left: 0;
                        right: 0;
                        bottom: 0;
                        background-color: hsla(0, 0%, 0%, 0.8);
                      }

                      We start the overlay as display none and then use JavaScript to switch it to display block. We position it so that it covers the entire screen and has a black 80% opaque background. So, it obscures most of the page content. The z-index needs to be a number higher than everything EXCEPT the modal window.

                       

                      Creating the Modal

                      The modal is similar to the overlay. It is a div, positioned on top of the rest of the page. It covers MOST of the page. There will still be part of the overlay visible around and behind the modal. 

                      HTML for the Modal:

                      <div class="modal">
                        <!-- content to show the user. Often this will contain a form -->
                        <button id="btnClose">Close | Save</button>
                      </div>

                      CSS for the Modal:

                      .modal{
                        display: none;
                        position: fixed; /* so it doesn't matter about scrolling */
                        z-index: 200;  /* some number higher than the overlay */
                        top: 10vh;
                        left: 10vw;
                        right: 10vw;
                        bottom: 10vh;
                        background-color: #e4e4e4;
                      }

                      The modal needs a z-index that is higher than the overlay. It will be position fixed to avoid any issues with the main page being scrolled. For it's top, right, bottom, and left values we want to use percentages to keep it contained, regardless of the size of the screen. If you use the % unit, many browsers will use the width of the parent element to calculate the size. While that works for the width, it can cause problems for the height of your modal. 

                      So, instead we use the vw and vh units. vw is a percentage of the viewport width and vh is a percentage of the viewport height. Alternatively we can provide a value for top and left and then use

                      width: 80vw;
                      height: 80vh;

                      Remember to provide a colour for your modal window. The default background is transparent.

                      The JavaScript to hide the modal

                      document.querySelector("#btnClose").addEventListener("click", function(ev){
                        ev.preventDefault();
                        /* if the button was a submit button we need to stop the form submitting */

                        document.querySelector(".overlay").style.display = "none";
                        document.querySelector(".modal").style.display = "none";
                        /* Add any code you need to process the contents of the form 
                          shown in the modal window */
                      });

                      To show the modal we would just do the reverse, set display = "block" for both divs.

                        Preparing your Android Environment

                        Before proceeding, you have a rather important decision to make: you can choose to develop your Android apps on Mac or Windows (or both if you really want to, but not recommended). If your preference is Windows, then be mindful and boot your Mac to run Windows natively. Running Windows as a virtual machine for your Android development would not be wise. You should know why.

                        Before choosing, please know this: I will be using my Mac exclusively for all of my Android development in this course.

                        The choice is now yours to make; you've made an informed choice.

                        Get the Java JDK

                        The Java programming language is used to create native Android applications.

                        For this course, you are instructed to use this version of the Java Development Kit (JDK): Java SE 8u92 (Links to an external site.)

                        Notes:

                        • we're Android developers, so we require the full JDK. The Java Runtime Edition (JRE) cannot be used to develop Java applications nor Android apps
                        • the JDK includes the JRE (but not vice-versa; see the previous statement :)

                        Reference Screen Shot

                        Accept Oracle's Licence Agreement:

                        The Android Integrated Development Environment (IDE)

                        "Android Studio is the official IDE for Android application development (source: http://developer.android.com/tools/studio)."

                        Download (Links to an external site.) the latest version of Android Studio for your preferred operating system (remember, Mac for me). Make sure the Android SDK tools are bundled too; this is the default behaviour.

                        Important Note Regarding Eclipse

                        Eclipse is no longer the preferred IDE for Android development, as it's been replaced by Android Studio. As such, I won't be accepting Eclipse-based Android projects.

                         

                        Verify Java

                        Verify you have the correct version of the Java compiler (javac) and the Java virtual machine (java).

                        javac is the Java compiler (man javac). Recall from your OOP course, the Java compiler takes your Java source files (*.java) and compiles them into Java byte files (*.class). The generated byte codes within the .class files are machine independent. That means Java runs on any platform that has a Java virtual machine (a.k.a java). The Java virtual machine --- simply known as java --- load the .class files and interprets the Java byte codes. Cool, eh?

                        On the Mac, open Terminal.app and run: javac -version

                        Next, run: java -version

                        Finally, run: env | grep '^JAVA_HOME\|^PATH' | sort

                        Your $PATH should be similar to mine:

                        What's important is that you see Java and Android in your $PATH. My $PATH includes others paths, such as /opt/local. It's OK if  you don't see /opt/bin (for example).

                        Previous Previous: Week 10 Summary Next Next: Installing the Android SDK

                        Installing the Android SDK

                        The Android SDK (Software Development Kit) is the software that lets you compile a Project written in Java into a runnable Android program.

                        The Android SDK can be downloaded and installed separately. However, when you install the Android Studio IDE, the SDK is included.

                        Downloading the SDK separately - https://developer.android.com/studio/index.html#downloads (Links to an external site.) in the Downloads section of this page look for the title "Get just the command line tools". 

                        Downloading the Android Studio IDE (with the SDK) - https://developer.android.com/studio/index.html (Links to an external site.) 

                        Here is an introductory guide to the interface of Android Studio - https://developer.android.com/studio/intro/index.html (Links to an external site.)

                         

                        Installing the Android Studio is the easiest way to install the SDK.

                        We will need the Android SDK installed to be able to use Cordova for the rest of the semester.

                         

                        Updating Android API versions

                        Whenever Google updates Android to a new version they give a name to the new version. They have moved through the alphabet in order. Eg: version 6.0 is API version 23 and called Marshmallow. version 7.0 is API version 24 and called Nougat.

                        http://source.android.com/source/build-numbers.html (Links to an external site.) provides a list of all the build numbers and names.

                        If you ever want a breakdown of the current usage of Android by version - https://developer.android.com/about/dashboards/index.html (Links to an external site.) - this page will provide updated statistics about once per month.

                         

                        To be able to build for the latest versions of Android, you need to install the latest API version. This will be used by the SDK to compile your project and create your app.

                        To launch the Android SDK Manager (Windows) from Android Studio: Tools > Android > SDK Manager.

                        On the OSX version go to the Android Studio menu > preferences > System Settings > Android

                        Alternatively, you can click the Launch Standalone SDK Manager link in the menu. I personally prefer this option but either will work.

                         

                        We should have API versions 21, 22, 23, 24, and 25.

                         

                         

                        Android Virtual Devices

                        Virtual Devices are a group of settings that define a virtual representation of an actual Android device. In order to test your applications you will use an Emulator. The emulator will need an AVD to know which version of the API to use and what hardware is available on the virtual device.

                         

                        Create an Android Virtual Device

                        Launch the Android Virtual Device Manager from Android Studio: Tools > Android > AVD Manager

                        Here is an example of Android Virtual Device (AVD) specifications:

                        1. Select Hardware
                          1. Category: Phone (Nexus 6, Size 5.96", Resolution 1440x2560, Density 560dpi)
                        2. System Image > Recommended (tab)
                          1. Marshmallow
                            1. API Level: 23
                            2. ABI: x86_64
                            3. Target: Android 6.0 (with Google APIs)
                        3. Show Advanced Settings
                          1. Camera
                            1. Front: None
                            2. Back: Webcam0
                        4. Change the AVD Name to: MAD9014

                         

                        Creating an AVD from the Command Line

                        From the command line it is actually possible to create AVDs. Here is a cheatsheet http://codepen.io/mad-d/pen/OPPyOw (Links to an external site.) on CodePen. It lists many Android and Cordova commands that you can call from the command line.

                        android create avd -n bob -t android-24

                        This line would create a new AVD with the name "bob" and include the API version 24.

                        android list avds

                        This command would provide you a list of AVDs that are currently available on your Macbook.

                         

                        Android SDK Emulator

                        The Android Emulator simulates a device and displays it on your development computer. It lets you prototype, develop, and test Android apps without using a hardware device.

                        The emulator supports Android phone, tablet, Android Wear, and Android TV devices. It comes with predefined device types so you can get started quickly, and you can create your own device definitions and emulator skins.

                        The emulator is installed with Android Studio and/or the Android SDK

                        Detailed information and full documentation is available here:

                        https://developer.android.com/studio/run/emulator.html (Links to an external site.)

                        Note: This emulator requires Intel HAXM to be installed.

                         

                        To run your Android app under the emulator, you need to first create an Android Virtual Devices (AVD). An AVD models a specific device. You can create AVDs to emulate different android devices (phone/tablet, android version, screen size etc..).W

                         

                        In Windows a "Nexus 5" virtual device is installed during the installation., you can use this to get started.

                         

                        On Mac

                        1. In Android studio, select "Tools" then Android then AVD Manager.
                        2. Click "Create Virtual Device".
                        3. Select a phone and complete the creation process.

                         

                        Visual Studio Android Emulator

                        The Visual Studio Android emulator boots and runs at nearly the speed of a physical device however, it requires Hyper-V Windows acceleration technology which is not compatible with HAXM.

                        You can run the Visual Studio Android emulator side-by-side with the Windows Phone Emulator and other Hyper-V virtual machines, the Visual Studio Emulator for Android works over remote desktop.

                        The Visual Studio Android emulator can be installed and used as a stand alone application, you do not need to install Visual studio.

                        An extensive set of device profiles for the most popular hardware in the market, including devices from Samsung, Motorola, Sony, LG, and more is available and very easy to install.

                         

                        More information is available here:

                        https://www.visualstudio.com/vs/msft-android-emulator/ (Links to an external site.)

                          Cordova Command Line Interface(CLI) reference - http://cordova.apache.org/docs/en/latest/reference/cordova-cli/index.html (Links to an external site.) 

                          Introduction to Cordova

                          Cordova | PhoneGap History

                          In 2011 Nitobi, the company that created PhoneGap, released the PhoneGap project to the Apache Open Source Foundation. The open source project is known as Cordova. The commerically available version is still known as PhoneGap. However, you will often see both names used interchangeably. PhoneGap was the original name and that is still what most people use to refer to the project.

                          The week after PhoneGap was released to the Apache Foundation Adobe announced its purchase of Nitobi and that the employees of Nitobi would be focused on continuing the development of PhoneGap / Cordova.

                          http://phonegap.com/ (Links to an external site.) - PhoneGap website

                          http://cordova.apache.org (Links to an external site.) - Cordova website

                          After Adobe acquired Nitobi and all their technical expertise on PhoneGap they immediately set to work integrating the PhoneGap technology into Dreamweaver. Now we can actually build our web app in Dreamweaver and then package it as "native" PhoneGap application directly from Dreamweaver. For professional development this commercial (paid) option is useful.

                          For learning and open-source projects, the free and open-source Cordova branch is ideal. We will be using Cordova for our work.

                          What is a Cordova / PhoneGap Application?

                          What is a Cordova / PhoneGap Application?

                          Here is a great video from 2012 with Brian Leroux (one of the PhoneGap creators) speaking to an HTML5 users group meeting. It explains what HTML5 is, what the Web APIs are, and what PhoneGap is.

                          http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=14MhSnFJ3dc (Links to an external site.)

                          With Cordova / PhoneGap you can take a mobile web app (a website built with HTML, CSS, and Javascript) compressed into only a few or even one HTML file, making sure that it is optimized for use on a mobile device and then, through the magic of the PhoneGap program, convert the HTML, CSS and Javascript into a native iOS, Android, Bada, BlackBerry, Symbian, WebOS, or Windows Phone application. Later on we will get back to how PhoneGap actually achieves this. For now, PhoneGap is just our wonderful magic black box which takes HTML, CSS and Javascript in one side and spits out native apps on the other side.

                          There are of course limitations to what you can do in a Cordova / PhoneGap Application and limitations in how and where you can create one. However, this cross-platform capability for building native apps with HTML, CSS and JavaScript is a tremendously powerful tool for web developers.

                          Cordova / PhoneGap has an additional JavaScript file which lets you write functions that speak to the native capabilities of smart phones and tablets.

                           

                          Working with Android Applications

                          Before we can create Cordova applications for Android, we need to install the Android SDK (Software Development Kit). You should have already installed this on Windows in MAD9111.

                          Once we have the Android SDK installed then we need to create a site in Dreamweaver, Brackets or your favorite text editor. This really is just pointing to a folder so Brackets, etc can view its contents as a succinct project and everything for that project is located inside that folder.

                          IMPORTANT NOTE:

                          Whenever you are building a Cordova App we need to start a new folder in Brackets (or Dreamweaver, Sublime, etc).

                           

                          PhoneGap Build Service

                          There are two ways to work with PhoneGap. One is to install PhoneGap on your computer and then use the PhoneGap Build Service through Dreamweaver. This is the Enterprise version of PhoneGap. PhoneGap Build uses Dreamweaver to upload your project and do the compilations to the various platforms for you. 

                          Cordova

                          The alternative to the PhoneGap Build Service is the Open Source version of PhoneGap known as Apache Cordova. 

                          With Cordova you will install the Cordova program on your computer along with the Android SDK and then use the command line to compile your project. This is the option that we will be using.

                          Cordova | PhoneGap Future 

                          Now that you have been introduced to the basic concepts and ideas behind PhoneGap you should be able to see how this can make the life much easier for a web developer looking to make mobile apps. That being said, the aim of the Cordova | PhoneGap project is to push cross-platform standards and make themselves obsolete.

                          The W3C's Device APIs and Policy (DAP) Working Group is working on standardizing the APIs for accessing native features in ALL mobile devices. They want developers to be able to use Javascript to access things like accelerometer, camera, contacts and compass. DAP wants to create a standard that can be implemented by all handset manufacturers.

                          If DAP succeeds then PhoneGap will be no longer necessary. PhoneGap's whole purpose is to let developers use JavaScript to access these native capabilities. The developers at Nitobi wrote native code that talks to the PhoneGap JavaScript methods. We use the PhoneGap Javascript methods in conjunction with our vanilla JavaScipt and other JavaScript libraries. to create our fully functional mobile apps.  

                           

                           

                          Preparing for Cordova

                          Preparing to Install Cordova | PhoneGap

                          Cordova is the tool that you will use to take your HTML, CSS and Javascript and bundle it as a native application on one or more mobile platforms.

                          To properly use Cordova we need to have the various SDKs for the different mobile platforms installed too. Those will often have their own prerequisites for installation.

                          In this course, for this term, we are only going to look at using Android and doing that from the Windows platform.

                          Make sure that you have installed Android on Windows (see The Module on the Android Sdk )

                           

                          "Cordova" and "PhoneGap"

                          The names "Cordova" and "PhoneGap" are sometimes used interchangeably. Wherever you see PhoneGap in the class readings, bear in mind that we will actually be using the open-source Apache Cordova.

                           

                          Cordova Prerequisites

                          To install Cordova on Windows (currently) we need to have Node.js installed. We are not going to be directly programming things with Node.js. Cordova uses Node.js to create its projects.

                          Visit http://nodejs.org/ (Links to an external site.) to download Node.js.

                          On the home page there are two buttons - one says "Install" and another says "downloads". The downloads button takes you to http://nodejs.org/download/ (Links to an external site.) which lists all the different versions of Node to be installed across various operating systems.

                          If you are currently on Windows then you can click the Install button and it will download and run the .msi file to install the latest version of Node.JS for Windows on your computer.

                          The default location for installing it is in your C:\Program Files\ folder. While this is fine and will work, I prefer to change it to C:\nodejs\ because it is shorter to type when creating the Environmental Variables. I do the same thing with Android, Java, and Ruby files.

                          The Node installation is a very simple install and only takes a minute or two.

                           

                          Cordova Dependencies

                          With Node.js we can install Cordova. However, to really do anything with Cordova we also need to install the various SDKs for the different Mobile operating systems - for example: Android, Windows Phone, BlackBerry, iOS, Tizen, WebOS, and FirefoxOS. Each has its own specific requirements.

                          We will be working with Android apps created through Cordova. This means that we need to install the Android SDK, Java JDK, and node.js. Older versions of PhoneGap require Ruby. Here are the reference links that I mention on other pages.

                           

                          Java JDK - http://www.oracle.com/technetwork/java/javase/downloads/jdk7-downloads-1880260.html (Links to an external site.)

                          Ruby for Windows - http://rubyinstaller.org/ (Links to an external site.) (we use this for SASS as well)

                          Android SDK - http://developer.android.com/sdk/index.html (Links to an external site.)

                          Node.js - http://nodejs.org/ (Links to an external site.)  

                           

                          Creating a Cordova Project

                          Installing Cordova | PhoneGap

                          Once you have installed your Android SDK (Installing Android Sdk) and Node.js (Preparing for Cordova) then you are ready to install Cordova on your computer.

                          Start here - https://cordova.apache.org (Links to an external site.)

                          The Cordova install process has changed many times over the last several years. The current install is to use the Node Package Manager (NPM). As long as you have Node.js installed properly then you should be able install Cordova from the command prompt. Run the Command Prompt AS ADMINSTRATOR - open the Windows menu, type command prompt, then right click on the Command Prompt program shown and select Run as administrator.

                          C:\> npm install -g cordova

                           

                          At the command prompt type the above. You should see something like this:

                           

                          This is the node package manager downloading and installing the different files required by Cordova.

                          We have installed Cordova so that it can be accessed globally, from anywhere in our computer.

                          When complete you should be able to run the command 

                          C:\> cordova -v

                          And see something like this:

                          Now we can see that we have Cordova installed and, more importantly which version we have.

                          Creating a Project

                          With Cordova installed we can now create a new project.

                          Navigate to a folder where you want to create your project folder. Do NOT create the folder itself. Just navigate to the place where you want to create the folder.

                          On the command line type the following.

                          cordova create MyFirstApp ca.edumedia.griffis.first MyAppName

                          This will call the Cordova command to create your folder, the project structure and assign the name and id properties to your app in the project's new config.xml file.

                          There are three things we write after "cordova create". 

                          The first is the internal id for the project. This will be saved inside the config.xml file that stores your app's configuration. It will also become the new project folder.

                          cd firstCordovaApp 
                          dir

                          These commands will take me inside the folder and show me the project structure.

                          The second string is the reverse-domain style identifier (namespace) for our new app. This style of naming is used to ensure uniqueness in our app names. When installing apps on devices this is the internal name. We need to make sure that this does not conflict with any other apps. Take your domain name from your account on edumedia. Eg: http://abcd0001.edumedia.ca/ (Links to an external site.) then remove the http:// part and reverse the order -> ca.edumedia.abcd0001. Finally, add the name of your app to the end of this string. 

                          Following this structure will ensure that your app never conflicts with or gets overwritten by anyone else's app in class.

                          The third string in the create options is the name for your app. This will be the visible name shown under the launcher icon on the device, after installation.

                          See here for the other CLI (Command Line Interface) commands - http://cordova.apache.org/docs/en/latest/reference/cordova-cli/index.html#cordova-create-command (Links to an external site.) 

                           

                          Directory Structure

                          After you have created your project, the directory structure will be something like this:

                          myapp/
|-- config.xml
|-- hooks/
|-- merges/
| | |-- android/
| | |-- windows/
| | |-- ios/
|-- www/
|-- platforms/
| |-- android/
| |-- windows/
| |-- ios/
|-- plugins/
  |--cordova-plugin-camera/

                           

                           

                          Other Platforms

                          When you want to use Cordova to build apps for platforms other than Android we need to set up the environments for those platforms too. Then we will be able to add the code for those platforms to our project structure and will be able to compile our hybrid app to run on those other platforms.

                          See - http://cordova.apache.org/docs/en/latest/guide/support/index.html (Links to an external site.) for support of the various platforms. 

                          For the links and instructions on setting up for platforms beyond Android.

                          Blackberry - http://cordova.apache.org/docs/en/latest/guide/platforms/blackberry10/home.html (Links to an external site.)

                          iOS - http://cordova.apache.org/docs/en/latest/guide/platforms/ios/index.html (Links to an external site.)

                          OSX - http://cordova.apache.org/docs/en/latest/guide/platforms/osx/index.html (Links to an external site.) 

                          Windows - http://cordova.apache.org/docs/en/latest/guide/platforms/win8/index.html (Links to an external site.) 

                          Ubuntu - http://cordova.apache.org/docs/en/latest/guide/platforms/ubuntu/index.html (Links to an external site.) 

                          Please note:

                          • iOS apps can only be created on Mac OSX.
                          • Windows Phone 7 apps can only be created on Windows Vista, Windows 7, or Windows 8.
                          • Windows Phone 8 apps can only be created on Windows 8+.
                          • Windows Phone 10 and Windows Universal need to be created on Windows 10+

                           

                           

                          Adding a Platform to a Cordova Project

                          So, now you have a Cordova Project. This means that you have an empty shell for creating a mobile app.

                          Inside the /www/ folder you will find a starter index.html and app.js file. This is where all your assets for your application go. You will do all your HTML, CSS, and JavaScript work inside this folder. Fonts, images, media files, and other libraries and frameworks all get saved here.

                          To build an Android App, we need to add the Android platform to our project. (this means all the starter files written in Java to create the shell for our application). All the files required to work with the Android SDK or iOS SDK will be added when you install a platform in your Cordova project.

                           

                          The Android SDK or the iOS SDK will have to be installed independently of this process.

                           

                          Adding Android to our project

                          There is a simple Cordova command that we run on the Command line to add any platform. Right now, we are on Windows and want to install Android for our app.

                          First, make sure that you are INSIDE your project's root folder. Then run this command.

                          cordova platform add android

                          If you are missing a requirement you might see something like this:

                          I did not have the needed version of the JDK installed on my computer (or did not have the Environmental Variables pointing to the correct version).

                          I need to update my JDK (or update my Environmental variables to point to the 1.8 version of the JDK).

                          Once I update my Environmental Variables:

                          Now, I can properly add the Android Platform. You can see in the second screenshot that I have variables called JAVA_HOME and CLASSPATH and PATH.

                          The first image is a list of everything that I have in my PATH. In the PATH variable I am using the JAVA_HOME variable to point to the correct version of Java. There is also a variable called ANDROID_HOME that I am using in my path. It was just off screen in the second screenshot.

                           

                          To run the platform add command again, I will need to restart my Command Prompt so that it picks up the latest version of these variables. The process, once working properly, will take longer and do a lot more work to get the project ready and hooked up with the Android SDK.

                          To see more of the commands for cordova platform, use this reference:

                          http://cordova.apache.org/docs/en/latest/reference/cordova-cli/index.html#cordova-platform-command (Links to an external site.) 

                          They include things like:

                          cordova platform remove android

                          Just in case you need to clear things out and start over.

                           

                           

                          Adding a Plugin to a Cordova Project

                          By now we have installed, updated, and configured:

                          1. Java JDK

                          2. Android SDK

                          3. Latest Android APIs

                          4. The Cordova program using NodeJS and NPM

                          5. Configured the Environmental Variables

                          6. Added the Android Platform to our project.

                           

                          We now have the ability to compile a true Android Application.

                          We can use all our HTML, CSS, and JavaScript skills to build a website and wrap it in the Cordova WebView container as an application.

                          The only limitation to what we build now is the fact that we have no more abilities than any browser does. The whole point of building an app is to access the abilities of a mobile device. Things like the Accelerometer, device properties, and the Camera are what truly give us a mobile experience.

                          For this we need plugins, more specifically, Cordova plugins.

                          The Cordova foundation and other developers from around the world have written plugins with Java for Android and Swift/Objective-C for iOS. (Also other plugins in other languages for other platforms).

                          The list of CORE Plugins: http://cordova.apache.org/docs/en/latest/#plugin-apis (Links to an external site.) 

                          The list of additional plugins: http://cordova.apache.org/plugins/ (Links to an external site.) 

                           

                          How to add a Plugin

                          Adding a plugin is very similar to adding a platform. We call the cordova command and pass in the options about which plugin to add to our project.

                          cordova plugin add cordova-plugin-battery-status

                          The last option in this command is the name of the plugin. The standard names for the plugins all start with "cordova-plugin-" followed by the descriptive name. All the core plugins follow this convention. Some plugins, written by independent developers or companies will have a differently formatted name.

                          If you want to search for plugins from the command line, you can do that too.

                          cordova plugin search keyword

                          To check which plugins are currently installed in your app:

                          cordova plugin ls

                           

                          More cordova plugin command options - http://cordova.apache.org/docs/en/latest/reference/cordova-cli/index.html#cordova-plugin-command (Links to an external site.) 

                          Videos: Getting started with Cordova

                          Here are two video's that will help you get started with Cordova:

                           

                          Installing Cordova (Links to an external site.)

                           

                          Creating a Cordova project, adding platforms and plugins and running your app on an emulator and/or browser (Links to an external site.)

                           

                          Custom CSS for a Specific Platform

                          We will be focusing on Android first in our mobile application development and design. That means gaining an understanding of the Material Design approach.

                          The official Android development website - https://developers.google.com/ (Links to an external site.) 

                          The official Android design website - https://developer.android.com/design/index.html (Links to an external site.) 

                          Simply put, Material Design is a mental approach to designing digital interfaces where everything should be thought of as a collection of physical paper elements. Every element has the same thickness. Every element can have a shadow. The spread of the shadow will indicate to the user how high the element is in relation to other elements from the background.

                          Another key thought is that material objects in the real world do not suddenly appear out of thin air, neither do they disappear. When adding elements to the screen you should make them come on to the screen or move off the screen in a clear way. When things are animated they will change shape or move in a predictable way. 

                          The official design guidelines are filled with great simple animated samples to show people what is and what is not allowed in a Material Design interface.

                          Start reading now and refer back often.

                           

                          Custom CSS in Cordova

                          When building apps with Cordova, we often use the same code-base to create both an Android and an iOS app. When it comes to CSS, many elements may have the same styling regardless of the platform. However, there will be differences. Cordova provides us with a way to address this.

                          The /merges/ folder will be where to place your custom css or scripts. Create a folder for each platform that you want. Eg:

                          merges/android/css/custom.css
                          merges/ios/css/custom.css

                          When compiling your app, the appropriate folder will be added to the app. Using the example above, it means that the 

                          css/custom.css 

                          folder and file will be copied to the /www/ folder.

                          If the folder and file exist in your /www/ folder already then the file will be overwritten.

                           

                           

                           

                          deviceready event

                          When we create websites that need JavaScript support, our typical approach is to use a DOMContentLoaded event listener.

                          document.addEventListener("DOMContentLoaded", init);

                          function init( ){
                            //start working with the webpage here
                          }

                          When it comes to mobile apps, the most important thing tends to be access to the plugins. plugins will take longer to activate than the browser will take to read through the DOM. Additionally, if you put your scripts at the bottom of the <body> in your HTML then the scripts will be running after the DOM is read anyway.

                          So, for mobile applications using Cordova, we need to wait for a special event called deviceready. This event tells us that the browser has read through the cordova.js file and then through the scripts for each included plugin and that they are ready to be used.

                          So, in our mobile app, once we start testing in an emulator or an actual device, this is the code we use:

                          document.addEventListener("deviceready", init);

                          function init(){
                            //mobile device is ready to play with us
                          }

                          REMEMBER: the browser on your desktop / laptop will NOT recognize this event, nor will it work with most plugins. You cannot test in your browser if you are using this event.

                           

                           

                          Testing Cordova App in Browser

                          As previously mentioned (on deviceready event ), we can't use the deviceready event when testing in the browser, only on a device or emulator.

                          That means we won't have access to the plugins or the actual features on the device if we are testing in a browser.

                          Testing in the browser means that we are really just testing our layout and our navigation.

                          There is a Cordova command that you can run from the command line to launch a server and serve up your application as a website:

                          cordova serve 3333

                          This would start a Node server and launch your www folder as a website on port 3333. This can be accessed from any browser on your computer. This is basically the same thing as live preview mode from Brackets.

                          However, you still won't have access to the plugins and actual device capabilities. 

                          Cordova Droid App

                          Re-submit Assignment
                          • Due Dec 13 by 11:59pm
                          • Points 40
                          • Submitting a website url

                          Here it is, the moment of truth, your first Android App built with the Cordova Framework. This is a joint final project with the MAD9010 Graphics Technology course. All the graphics and icons for this app will be created as your final for MAD9010.

                          ...More details will be added after discussions in class...

                           

                          You will be building a Sport Themed app to display a game schedule and scores from games played. 

                          You can choose between Hockey, Football (Soccer), Cricket, Baseball, or Quidditch.

                          The data for the app is being randomly generated by scripts that we have created for you.

                          Hockey - https://griffis.edumedia.ca/mad9014/sports/hockey.php (Links to an external site.) 

                          Football - https://griffis.edumedia.ca/mad9014/sports/soccer.php (Links to an external site.) 

                          Cricket - https://griffis.edumedia.ca/mad9014/sports/cricket.php (Links to an external site.) 

                          Baseball - https://griffis.edumedia.ca/mad9014/sports/baseball.php (Links to an external site.) 

                          Quidditch - https://griffis.edumedia.ca/mad9014/sports/quidditch.php (Links to an external site.) 

                          Basketball - https://griffis.edumedia.ca/mad9014/sports/basketball.php (Links to an external site.) 

                          Each time you make a call to a page you will get a new random set of data.

                           

                          Interface Requirements

                          Create your app as a Single Page App. There must be two screens in your app. One that shows the timetable (schedule) of all the games from the data. The second needs to show all the scores for the teams, ranked by the number of games won.

                          Your app needs to have a launcher icon, a splashscreen graphic, icons and text on the navigation tabs, and an icon for each team.

                          The nav menu will have two tabs - timetable and scores. For the icons on the nav buttons you can use the iconic icon set, same as the MAD9013 final. iconic-everything-1.9.0.zip

                          This page - https://algonquin.instructure.com/courses/501987/pages/handling-long-text-and-hyphens?module_item_id=9989609 should be helpful when dealing with lots of text in small spaces.

                           

                          Functional Requirements

                          When the app launches, it needs to fetch the data from the server and save it to localStorage. The next time you launch the app, it should check to see if the data is in localStorage and if the data is there then do NOT load new data.

                          The app should have some type of refresh button. If the user taps the refresh button then the data in localStorage needs to be replaced. You can use the "reload" icon from the iconic set if you want for this button.

                          Your will need to sort the data by dates to display the timetable of games. Numeric or Multi-dimensional Sorting

                          You will need to calculate the number of wins, losses, and ties and then sort the data by that information to display the scores.

                           

                          Submission

                          When you create your app, make sure that you name your app your username. You can edit your config.xml file to change it. On the phone we should see an app with your launcher icon plus your username. Eg: ABCD0001.

                          Also make sure that your package name includes your username so you are not overwriting anyone else's app.

                           

                          There are two parts to the submission.

                          1. Install your app on one of the Android Phones from the cabinet. Leave the name of the phone you used as a note here.

                          2. Upload your project to GitHub as a new Repo. Submit the URL of your Repo here. (This means your WHOLE CORDOVA folder)

                           

                          Challenge Feature

                          Often when working data we will want to "cache" that information. This means that we want to save the data locally but only for a specific amount of time. In this application that means that we would hang onto data stored in localStorage but for a limited time before we request a new copy.

                          When the deviceready / DOMContentLoaded event is triggered, we will need to check a timestamp saved in localStorage at the same time that the sport data was saved. This timestamp can be part of the sports data or a separate key. Compare this timestamp to the current time on the device. If the difference between the two times is more than one hour then we will make a new fetch( ) call to the server for a new copy of the data. Once the new data is received, we would replace the data in localStorage, set a new timestamp in localStorage, and then update the interface with the new data.
