                            Cordova Device and Console Plugins

                            When working with Cordova, you will be frequently adding plugins to extend what you can do with JavaScript. The device plugin is a common one. http://cordova.apache.org/docs/en/latest/reference/cordova-plugin-device/index.html (Links to an external site.)

                            This plugin will let you access things like the device name, operating system, and a unique id for the device. 

                            To add it to your project, open the command prompt (terminal window) and navigate to your project folder. From inside the folder run this command.

                            cordova plugin add cordova-plugin-device

                            That will add the device plugin for you. Then you can use it from your own JavaScript. 

                            document.addEventListener("deviceready", function(){
                              console.log( device.platform );
                              console.log( device.version );
                              console.log( device.manufacturer );
                              console.log( device.uuid );
                              console.log( device.model );
                              console.log( device.serial );
                            }); 

                            The above code would give you a list of details about the device that is currently running the code.

                            Unfortunately, we do not have access to the console by default. Using the console and seeing the output requires another plugin be added to our project.

                            cordova plugin add cordova-plugin-console

                            With the console plugin added, we can now see the output of our console.log statements.

                            From the command window enter:

                            monitor

                            This will launch the Android monitor and allow us to see the output from our Cordova console.log statements. See below for a screenshot of the monitor.

                             Every bit of information that the emulator or connected device outputs will be displayed here.

                             

                            Cordova config.xml

                            Here is a sample of the config.xml file:

                            <?xml version='1.0' encoding='utf-8'?>
                            <widget id="ca.edumedia.griffis.myapp" version="0.0.1" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/ns/widgets" xmlns:cdv="http://cordova.apache.org/ns/1.0">
                             <name>TheApp</name>
                             <description>
                             A sample Apache Cordova application that responds to the deviceready event.
                             </description>
                             <author email="dev@cordova.apache.org" href="http://cordova.io">
                             Apache Cordova Team
                             </author>
                             <content src="index.html" />
                             <plugin name="cordova-plugin-whitelist" spec="1" />
                             <access origin="*" />
                             <allow-intent href="http://*/*" />
                             <allow-intent href="https://*/*" />
                             <allow-intent href="tel:*" />
                             <allow-intent href="sms:*" />
                             <allow-intent href="mailto:*" />
                             <allow-intent href="geo:*" />
                             <platform name="android">
                             <allow-intent href="market:*" />
                             </platform>
                             <platform name="ios">
                             <allow-intent href="itms:*" />
                             <allow-intent href="itms-apps:*" />
                             </platform>
                            </widget>

                            This is the configuration file for your Cordova project. It defines the internal name, the external name, and the version for your application.

                            You can edit this file directly to change the version of your app, the name that the user sees or the name that the phone will use to identify your app. The internal name is the id attribute.

                            The <name> element is the name the user sees.

                            The <author> element is something that you should edit to add your own name and email address.

                            The other elements in the config.xml file have to do with permissions for your application.

                             

                            Note: We are currently using version 6 of Cordova. When version 7 comes out, we will no longer be using a config.xml file. Instead, there will be a package.json file with all this information. That will bring Cordova inline with other projects that have been built with Node and NPM.

                             

                            Cordova Version Management

                            Application Versions

                            When you want to change the version of your app, because you have fixed bugs or added new features, go to the config.xml file and edit the version attribute in the main widget element.

                            <widget id="ca.edumedia.griffis.myapp" version="0.0.1" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/ns/widgets" xmlns:cdv="http://cordova.apache.org/ns/1.0">

                            If it is a bug fix then change the last digit. Eg:  0.0.1  =>  0.0.2 (patch number)

                            If it is a new feature or a new way of programming a feature then usually it is a minor version change. Eg: 0.0.2 => 0.1.0

                            If you are making a large change that really alters the interface and how your app works then you should make a major version change.  Eg:  0.1.0 =>  1.0.0

                             

                            Update Your Version of Cordova

                            You can always tell which version of Cordova you are running by going to the Terminal and typing:

                            cordova -v

                            This will tell you the version of Cordova.

                            Keep in mind that there is a version for Cordova, but there are also versions of each platform for Cordova.

                            Updating Cordova will give you access to the latest versions of the platforms.

                            npm install -g cordova

                            And then in your project you can always remove and re-add the platform to get the latest.

                            cordova platform remove android
                            cordova platform add android

                            If for some reason you need to add a specific version of cordova-android( https://github.com/apache/cordova-android (Links to an external site.) ) to match an old project then you can add the version when you add the platform

                            cordova platform add android@4.1.1

                            Alternatively, we can ask to update just the cordova-android part of our app.

                            cordova platform update android@5.0.0

                            Version 5.0.0 of the Cordova android platform adds support for Android Marshmallow. The most significant impact of this update is the fact that permission management changed in Android Marshmallow. Version 5.x of android-cordova handles these permissions properly.

                            https://cordova.apache.org/docs/en/latest/guide/platforms/android/upgrade.html#upgrading-plugins-for-android-marshmallow (Links to an external site.)

                            Here is a list of the permissions that Android deems dangerous

                            https://developer.android.com/guide/topics/security/permissions.html#perm-groups (Links to an external site.)

                            With any plugin that uses those permissions we need to be using android-cordova 5.x+

                             

                             

                             

                            Cordova Content-Security-Policy Meta Tag

                            https://content-security-policy.com/ (Links to an external site.)

                            This website describes all the details of the new <meta> tag that appears in all Cordova Apps.

                            If you look inside the <head> of your index.html file, from your Cordova www folder then you will see this:

                            <meta http-equiv="Content-Security-Policy" content="default-src 'self' data: gap: https://ssl.gstatic.com 'unsafe-eval'; style-src 'self' 'unsafe-inline'; media-src *">

                            This meta tag defines what type of content can be loaded from which sources.

                            Inside the content attribute is a list of possible types of things to load and the sources from which they are allowed to be loaded.

                            default-src is the default policy for loading content such as JavaScript, Images, CSS, Font's, AJAX requests, Frames, HTML5 Media. In the example above, 'self', data:, and gap: are used as the defaults. That means when there is no specific value given for one of those things then it must be loaded from inside the www folder, or begin with a data: or gap: URL.

                            style-src is the policy for loading CSS files. In the example above 'self' is being used. So CSS must be inside the www folder (or from the same domain for web apps)

                            media-src is the policy for loading audio and video.

                            font-src gets used to load fonts.

                            img-src gets used to load images.

                            connect-src gets used to make AJAX calls with XMLHttpRequest or fetch.

                            There are others as well that you can find on the CSP website, but these are the most common. The values that you can enter for each of these policies can be found here: https://content-security-policy.com/#source_list (Links to an external site.)

                            'self' was already mentioned. This will allow anything from the local device or same domain.

                            * allows anything except for data: or other blob or filesystem formats.

                            data: allows anything being loaded as a data-uri (base-64 encoded).

                            gap: refers to internal phonegap references. It is always a good idea to keep this in the default-src policy to prevent permission errors that are hard to debug.

                            'none' will prevent anything of that type from being loaded

                            *.example.com would allow any subdomain from example.com to be used.

                            https: would allow anything being loaded over https.

                             

                             

                            Cordova Whitelist Plugin for Android

                            The whitelist plugin for Android is automatically added now when you add the Android platform to your project.

                            It's purpose is to manage, much like the security policy meta tag, the permissions for navigating in your app.

                            https://cordova.apache.org/docs/en/latest/reference/cordova-plugin-whitelist/index.html (Links to an external site.)

                            With the whitelist, we are specifically talking about where we can navigate to within the WebView belonging to the app.

                             

                            By default, navigations only to file:// URLs, are allowed. To allow others URLs, you must add <allow-navigation> tags to your config.xml:

                            <!-- Allow links to example.com -->
<allow-navigation href="http://example.com/*" />

<!-- Wildcards are allowed for the protocol, as a prefix
     to the host, or as a suffix to the path -->
<allow-navigation href="*://*.example.com/*" />

<!-- A wildcard can be used to whitelist the entire network,
     over HTTP and HTTPS.
     *NOT RECOMMENDED* -->
<allow-navigation href="*" />

<!-- The above is equivalent to these three declarations -->
<allow-navigation href="http://*/*" />
<allow-navigation href="https://*/*" />
<allow-navigation href="data:*" />

                             

                             

                            Running the Android Emulator

                            The Android Emulator

                            Each of our development platforms (Android, Windows Phone, and iOS) has a program that simulates how a program would run on one of those devices. For some platforms it is called an emulator and for others it is called a simulator. The name is not important.

                            What is important is that we have a way of testing our apps.

                             

                            Creating AVDs

                            In order to run the emulator and have it pretend to be different phones we need to create "images" of what those devices can do and how big they are. These "images" are called Android Virtual Devices (AVDs). Through the Android SDK Manager we can set up one or more AVDs.

                            Run the SDK Manager from the command line or from the windows start menu. (Search for Android SDK Manager). I have mine pinned to the start screen.

                            From the Tools menu select Manage AVDs...:

                            Then you can click on the New button to create a new AVD:

                            Create a name for the AVD. Usually, I include the API version and the name of the device in my AVD name.

                            Pick a device from the list.

                            The target is the API version you want to set as a minimum level. In this example I was using API level 19. It is best to use the Google APIs (Google Inc.) version of the API.

                            Check the box near the bottom that says "Snapshot" if you want to have it save the current status of your app for the next time you run the emulator with that AVD.

                            Click OK to create the AVD.

                             

                            Starting the Emulator

                             From the command line you can start the emulator by typing:

                            C:\> emulator -avd mynexus

                            Where mynexus is the name of my AVD. Replace that part with the name you chose for your AVD.

                            Depending on the processor in your computer the emulator can take a couple minutes to start running. With a really good processor I would expect the first run of the emulator to start within 30 seconds. To be ready to launch your apps could take a couple minutes. This process is much like turning your phone on for the first time.

                            The alternate way to start it is from the Android SDK Manager -  AVD manager. Select your AVD from the list and click the Start button on the right.

                            Once the Emulator is running with your AVD, and you see the home screen for the phone you should be able to run the phonegap command to build and launch your app in the emulator. If the emulator is running PhoneGap will automatically deploy to that AVD.

                             

                            Debugging Your App

                            When you are running your app in the emulator you can have a console to see the Javascript errors that occur. There are two choices.

                            The alternate method is the Dalvik Debug Monitor that comes with the Android SDK. It is a program with a nicer interface than the command line log. From the command window enter:

                            monitor

                            You need to leave the cmd window open or the monitor window will close as well. 

                            The monitor program can be found inside your Android SDK folder. Look inside the tools folder and you will see the monitor.bat file.

                             

                            Installing an APK file on an Android Device

                            Installing on an Android Device

                            The .apk file is the application to be installed on your device. All mobile Android devices will be able to connect to your Macbook via USB. However, the default for most is to connect for file transfers - for music and images.

                            We want to be able to treat the phone as a location where ADB can install applications. This usually involves installing drivers and other software on your Macbook so it can recognize the Android device in the manner we need.

                             

                            Installing Samsung Device Drivers

                            Samsung devices use a program called KIES.

                            http://www.samsung.com/hk_en/support/skp/faq/1058166 (Links to an external site.) 

                            This is the link to find the KIES application for Windows and Mac OSX for Samsung Android devices for Android 4.4 and up. With a quick search on the Samsung site, or through Google, you should be able to find the version of KIES that has the correct drivers for the phone you need.

                            After you download and install KIES, connect your phone via USB to your Macbook and you will see that KIES detects the device and will start to install the drivers.

                             

                            See the bottom item in the image above? SAMSUNG Android ADB Interface. ADB is what we will use from the command line to install the application on the device.

                            Installing Drivers for Nexus, LG or Other Android Phones

                            Refer to the course Module on Android. There are links to download drivers for Nexus and LG phones.

                            Other manufacturers have similar programs. Here is a link from the Android Developer site for a bunch of generic drivers for windows

                            http://developer.android.com/tools/extras/oem-usb.html (Links to an external site.)

                             

                            Using Android Device Bridge (adb)

                            After the drivers are installed open the command window.

                            > adb devices

                            This command should list all devices that are connected to the computer as well as any emulator that is running. For example

                            > adb devices
List of devices attached
emulator-5554  device
emulator-5556  device
emulator-5558  device

                            To direct commands to a specific emulator or physical Android device attached to your laptop, use the -s option as follows:

                            adb -s <serialNumber> <command>

                            Replace <serialNumber> and <command> with the actual device number and the command you want to run, for example:

                            adb -s emulator-5556 install helloWorld.apk

                            This command installs the "helloWorld.apk" Android app onto the virtual device named "emulator-5556".

                            Here is a link that provides a bit more general information about setting up your app and your device for testing and debugging.

                            https://developer.android.com/tools/device.html (Links to an external site.) 

                            And here is the reference from the Android Developer site for the ADB command line tool

                            http://developer.android.com/tools/help/adb.html (Links to an external site.) 

                             

                            Setting Developer Mode on Android Phones

                            One last thing to note is that devices often need to have a "developer mode" turned on so you can install through USB and test apps.

                            Look under the "Settings" menu on the Android device to find this and enable the various settings you need.

                             

                            Uninstalling Apps from Devices

                            If you ever want to uninstall an application from the command line you can use ADB to do that too.

                            > adb uninstall name-of-app-package

                             

                            To find the name of the app package to uninstall it you would type this on the command line:

                            > shell pm list packages

                             

                             

                            Installing an APK file on an Android Device

                            Installing on an Android Device

                            The .apk file is the application to be installed on your device. All mobile Android devices will be able to connect to your Macbook via USB. However, the default for most is to connect for file transfers - for music and images.

                            We want to be able to treat the phone as a location where ADB can install applications. This usually involves installing drivers and other software on your Macbook so it can recognize the Android device in the manner we need.

                            http://www.samsung.com/hk_en/support/skp/faq/1058166 (Links to an external site.) 

                            This is the link to find the KIES application for Windows and Mac OSX for Samsung Android devices for Android 4.4 and up. With a quick search on the Samsung site, or through Google, you should be able to find the version of KIES that has the correct drivers for the phone you need.

                            See the bottom item in the image above? SAMSUNG Android ADB Interface. ADB is what we will use from the command line to install the application on the device.

                            Installing Drivers for Nexus, LG or Other Android Phones

                            Refer to the course Module on Android. There are links to download drivers for Nexus and LG phones.

                            Using Android Device Bridge (adb)

                            After the drivers are installed open the command window.

                            > adb devices

                            This command should list all devices that are connected to the computer as well as any emulator that is running. For example

                            > adb devices
List of devices attached
emulator-5554  device
emulator-5556  device
emulator-5558  device

                            To direct commands to a specific emulator or physical Android device attached to your laptop, use the -s option as follows:

                            adb -s <serialNumber> <command>

                            Replace <serialNumber> and <command> with the actual device number and the command you want to run, for example:

                            adb -s emulator-5556 install helloWorld.apk

                            This command installs the "helloWorld.apk" Android app onto the virtual device named "emulator-5556".

                            Here is a link that provides a bit more general information about setting up your app and your device for testing and debugging.

                            https://developer.android.com/tools/device.html (Links to an external site.) 

                            And here is the reference from the Android Developer site for the ADB command line tool

                            http://developer.android.com/tools/help/adb.html (Links to an external site.) 

                             

                            Setting Developer Mode on Android Phones

                            One last thing to note is that devices often need to have a "developer mode" turned on so you can install through USB and test apps.

                            Look under the "Settings" menu on the Android device to find this and enable the various settings you need.

                             

                            Uninstalling Apps from Devices

                            If you ever want to uninstall an application from the command line you can use ADB to do that too.

                            > adb uninstall name-of-app-package

                             

                            To find the name of the app package to uninstall it you would type this on the command line:

                            > shell pm list packages

                             

                             

                            Cordova Droid App

                            Re-submit Assignment
                            • Due Dec 13 by 11:59pm
                            • Points 40
                            • Submitting a website url

                            Here it is, the moment of truth, your first Android App built with the Cordova Framework. This is a joint final project with the MAD9010 Graphics Technology course. All the graphics and icons for this app will be created as your final for MAD9010.

                            ...More details will be added after discussions in class...

                             

                            You will be building a Sport Themed app to display a game schedule and scores from games played. 

                            You can choose between Hockey, Football (Soccer), Cricket, Baseball, or Quidditch.

                            The data for the app is being randomly generated by scripts that we have created for you.

                            Hockey - https://griffis.edumedia.ca/mad9014/sports/hockey.php (Links to an external site.) 

                            Football - https://griffis.edumedia.ca/mad9014/sports/soccer.php (Links to an external site.) 

                            Cricket - https://griffis.edumedia.ca/mad9014/sports/cricket.php (Links to an external site.) 

                            Baseball - https://griffis.edumedia.ca/mad9014/sports/baseball.php (Links to an external site.) 

                            Quidditch - https://griffis.edumedia.ca/mad9014/sports/quidditch.php (Links to an external site.) 

                            Basketball - https://griffis.edumedia.ca/mad9014/sports/basketball.php (Links to an external site.) 

                            Each time you make a call to a page you will get a new random set of data.

                             

                            Interface Requirements

                            Create your app as a Single Page App. There must be two screens in your app. One that shows the timetable (schedule) of all the games from the data. The second needs to show all the scores for the teams, ranked by the number of games won.

                            Your app needs to have a launcher icon, a splashscreen graphic, icons and text on the navigation tabs, and an icon for each team.

                            The nav menu will have two tabs - timetable and scores. For the icons on the nav buttons you can use the iconic icon set, same as the MAD9013 final. iconic-everything-1.9.0.zip

                            This page - https://algonquin.instructure.com/courses/501987/pages/handling-long-text-and-hyphens?module_item_id=9989609 should be helpful when dealing with lots of text in small spaces.

                             

                            Functional Requirements

                            When the app launches, it needs to fetch the data from the server and save it to localStorage. The next time you launch the app, it should check to see if the data is in localStorage and if the data is there then do NOT load new data.

                            The app should have some type of refresh button. If the user taps the refresh button then the data in localStorage needs to be replaced. You can use the "reload" icon from the iconic set if you want for this button.

                            Your will need to sort the data by dates to display the timetable of games. Numeric or Multi-dimensional Sorting

                            You will need to calculate the number of wins, losses, and ties and then sort the data by that information to display the scores.

                             

                            Submission

                            When you create your app, make sure that you name your app your username. You can edit your config.xml file to change it. On the phone we should see an app with your launcher icon plus your username. Eg: ABCD0001.

                            Also make sure that your package name includes your username so you are not overwriting anyone else's app.

                             

                            There are two parts to the submission.

                            1. Install your app on one of the Android Phones from the cabinet. Leave the name of the phone you used as a note here.

                            2. Upload your project to GitHub as a new Repo. Submit the URL of your Repo here. (This means your WHOLE CORDOVA folder)

                             

                            Challenge Feature

                            Often when working data we will want to "cache" that information. This means that we want to save the data locally but only for a specific amount of time. In this application that means that we would hang onto data stored in localStorage but for a limited time before we request a new copy.

                            When the deviceready / DOMContentLoaded event is triggered, we will need to check a timestamp saved in localStorage at the same time that the sport data was saved. This timestamp can be part of the sports data or a separate key. Compare this timestamp to the current time on the device. If the difference between the two times is more than one hour then we will make a new fetch( ) call to the server for a new copy of the data. Once the new data is received, we would replace the data in localStorage, set a new timestamp in localStorage, and then update the interface with the new data.

                            Week 13 Summary

                             

                            Learning Objective: By the end of this week, students will have demonstrated the following: How to build an Android Hybrid Mobile Application with Cordova.

                             

                            a
                            Prior to Class During Class Following Class
                            • Review material from first twelve weeks
                            • Read the contents of Module 12
                            • Finish the LocalStorage Contacts assignment 
                            • Finish the JS Best Practices assignment
                            		 The learning activities for this week will include:

                               

                               

                              Cordova Launcher Icons

                              By default, Cordova has it's own icon that gets deployed as the launcher icon. If you want to override their icon with your own you will need to save the icon at a variety of sizes.

                              To add the icon to your project, you will need to add a series of <icon> elements inside of a <platform> element.

                              Here is the list of the sizes for Android.

                                  <platform name="android">
        <!--
            ldpi    : 36x36 px
            mdpi    : 48x48 px
            hdpi    : 72x72 px
            xhdpi   : 96x96 px
            xxhdpi  : 144x144 px
            xxxhdpi : 192x192 px
        -->
        <icon src="res/android/ldpi.png" density="ldpi" />
        <icon src="res/android/mdpi.png" density="mdpi" />
        <icon src="res/android/hdpi.png" density="hdpi" />
        <icon src="res/android/xhdpi.png" density="xhdpi" />
        <icon src="res/android/xxhdpi.png" density="xxhdpi" />
        <icon src="res/android/xxxhdpi.png" density="xxxhdpi" />
    </platform>

                              The path written inside of the src attribute, pointing to the location of the icon is relative to the root project folder.

                               

                              Cordova Splashscreens

                              Custom splashscreens in Cordova apps are like the custom icons. We add the paths for the splashscreen images to the config.xml file.

                              The difference between the splashscreens and the icons is that the splashscreens have two different orientations - portrait and landscape. We need to have an image for each resolution AND each orientation.

                              <platform name="android">
    <!-- you can use any density that exists in the Android project -->
    <splash src="res/screen/android/splash-land-hdpi.png" density="land-hdpi"/>
    <splash src="res/screen/android/splash-land-ldpi.png" density="land-ldpi"/>
    <splash src="res/screen/android/splash-land-mdpi.png" density="land-mdpi"/>
    <splash src="res/screen/android/splash-land-xhdpi.png" density="land-xhdpi"/>

    <splash src="res/screen/android/splash-port-hdpi.png" density="port-hdpi"/>
    <splash src="res/screen/android/splash-port-ldpi.png" density="port-ldpi"/>
    <splash src="res/screen/android/splash-port-mdpi.png" density="port-mdpi"/>
    <splash src="res/screen/android/splash-port-xhdpi.png" density="port-xhdpi"/>
</platform>

                              Just like the icons, the path written in the src attribute is relative to the project root.

                              The sizes for the splashscreens are:

                              • MDPI: Portrait: 320x480px. Landscape: 480x320px.
                              • HDPI: Portrait: 480x800px. Landscape: 800x480px.
                              • XHDPI: Portrait: 720px1280px. Landscape: 1280x720px.
                              • XXHDPI: Portrait: 960px1600px. Landscape: 1600x960px.
                              • XXXHDPI: Portrait: 1280px1920px. Landscape: 1920x1280px.

                               

                               

                              Single Page Applications (SPA)

                              What is a SPA?

                              A Single Page Application (SPA) is a single HTML file that contains a series of <div>s or <section>s that are displayed as if they are separate web pages.

                              We will use CSS to display only one of the "pages" at a time. They will be stacked one on top of the other. Each "page" will be styled to fill the entire screen.

                              The navigation menu will typically be placed as a bar across the bottom of the screen.

                              In most cases, when people are building SPAs they will add custom attributes to the "pages" and the navigation area. 

                              <div data-role="page" id="home" class="active">
                                <!-- the contents of the page would be here -->
                              </div>

                              We can control the appearance of the pages by using CSS attribute selectors.

                              [data-role="page"]{
                                /* the CSS to make the section appear as if it is the whole page */
                                width: 100%;
                                position: absolute;
                                top: 0;
                                min-height: 100vh;
                              } 

                              More about custom data- attributes. http://html5doctor.com/html5-custom-data-attributes/ (Links to an external site.) 

                              We make the sections use position: absolute; if the content could be taller than the screen. If the content will never be as tall or taller than the screen then we can use position: fixed;.

                               

                               

                              Navigating between "pages"

                              Creating Pages

                              When building SPAs, we are using a single HTML file. However, to the user it needs to appear as if there are multiple pages. The common approach to achieving this is to use a data- property or a CSS class name to indicate which HTML elements are the pages.

                              <body>
                                <section data-role="page" id="one" class="active">
                                  <h2>Page One</h2>
                                </section>
                                <section data-role="page" id="two" class="">
                                  <h2>Page Two</h2>
                                </section>
                              </body>

                              This example shows two pages within the <body>, using an attribute called "data-role". This attribute is just a made-up attribute like all other data- attributes.

                              In order to know which page is the currently visible one and which one should be hidden, we will use a CSS class called "active". The presence or absence of this className lets us know which page is being displayed to the user.

                              [data-role=page]{
                                display: none;  /* default state */
                                z-index: 10;
                                position: absolute;
                                top:0;
                                left: 0;
                                right: 0;
                                min-height: 90vh;
                              }
                              [data-role=page].active{
                                display: block;
                                z-index: 20;
                              }

                               

                              Navigation

                              There are two ways to create navigation menus in an SPA. First is to add a navigation area inside each of the sections. Second is to create a navigation area outside of all the pages. 

                              <section data-role="nav">
                                <ul>
                                  <li><a href="#one" class="active">One</a></li>
                                  <li><a href="#two" class="">Two</a></li>
                                </ul>
                              </section>

                              Whether or not you put this section inside the page or outside the page, we need to be able to visually indicate which page is the current one. We can use the same className as the one that we use for the pages.

                              [data-role=nav]{
                                position: absolute;
                                bottom: 0;
                                width: 100%;
                                height: 10vh;
                                z-index: 30;  /* higher than the pages */
                              }
                              [data-role=nav] .active{ 
                                background-color: /* something with more contrast */
                                font-weight: bold;
                              }

                              We are positioning the nav section at the bottom of the page, with a z-index that is higher than any of the pages.

                               

                               

                              Scripting the Pages

                              After the DOMContentLoaded event (or the deviceready event when using Cordova) we can start scripting with all the pages. We will loop through all the "pages" which are saved in a global variable.

                              var pages = document.querySelectorAll('[data-role="pages"]');
                              var links = document.querySelectorAll('[data-role="nav"] a]');

                              By default, all the pages will be hidden. We will use JavaScript to add and remove the "active" classNames.

                              pages[0].className = "active";
                              links[0].className = "active";

                              First page element in the array will be set to active by adding a CSS class. This CSS class will determine whether pages are visible or hidden.

                              Clicking on a tab or main navigation button will call a function. The function will read the href from the tab or link. All pages will have the "active" class removed. The page that matches the href from the anchor will have the active class added.

                              [].forEach.call(links, function(item){
                                item.addEventListener("click", navigate);
                              }); 

                              function navigate(ev){
                                //user clicked on one of the tabs
                                ev.preventDefault();
                                let url = ev.currentTarget.href;  
                                //the href will end with something like "#one"
                                let id = url.split("#")[1];
                                [].forEach.call(pages, function(item){
                                  if(item.id == id){
                                    page.className = "active";
                                  }else{
                                    page.className = "";
                                  }
                                });
                              }

                              We need to call the preventDefault method to stop the anchor click from making the html file being reloaded.

                              We loop through the pages looking for one whose id matches the href from the anchor tags that was clicked. When there is a match, we make that <section> the one with the class "active". We also remove the class active from ALL other <section>s.

                               

                              Keep in mind that this example only shows two pages. However, this code will work for any number of "pages".

                               

                              Android Style Guide

                              Material Design is the name of the official Google style guide for Android Apps.

                              Android Material Design Style Guide - https://material.google.com/ (Links to an external site.) 

                               

                              The Guide contains instructions on how to design your app to meet the parameters of Material Design. There are pages about:

                              Typography - https://material.google.com/style/typography.html (Links to an external site.) 

                              Colour use - https://material.google.com/style/color.html (Links to an external site.) 

                              Icons - https://material.google.com/style/icons.html (Links to an external site.)  

                              Bottom Navigation for multiple pages - https://material.google.com/components/bottom-navigation.html# (Links to an external site.) 

                              Tabbed Navigation for 2 or 3 pages - https://material.google.com/components/tabs.html# (Links to an external site.) 

                               

                              Cordova Droid App

                              Re-submit Assignment
                              • Due Dec 13 by 11:59pm
                              • Points 40
                              • Submitting a website url

                              Here it is, the moment of truth, your first Android App built with the Cordova Framework. This is a joint final project with the MAD9010 Graphics Technology course. All the graphics and icons for this app will be created as your final for MAD9010.

                              ...More details will be added after discussions in class...

                               

                              You will be building a Sport Themed app to display a game schedule and scores from games played. 

                              You can choose between Hockey, Football (Soccer), Cricket, Baseball, or Quidditch.

                              The data for the app is being randomly generated by scripts that we have created for you.

                              Hockey - https://griffis.edumedia.ca/mad9014/sports/hockey.php (Links to an external site.) 

                              Football - https://griffis.edumedia.ca/mad9014/sports/soccer.php (Links to an external site.) 

                              Cricket - https://griffis.edumedia.ca/mad9014/sports/cricket.php (Links to an external site.) 

                              Baseball - https://griffis.edumedia.ca/mad9014/sports/baseball.php (Links to an external site.) 

                              Quidditch - https://griffis.edumedia.ca/mad9014/sports/quidditch.php (Links to an external site.) 

                              Basketball - https://griffis.edumedia.ca/mad9014/sports/basketball.php (Links to an external site.) 

                              Each time you make a call to a page you will get a new random set of data.

                               

                              Interface Requirements

                              Create your app as a Single Page App. There must be two screens in your app. One that shows the timetable (schedule) of all the games from the data. The second needs to show all the scores for the teams, ranked by the number of games won.

                              Your app needs to have a launcher icon, a splashscreen graphic, icons and text on the navigation tabs, and an icon for each team.

                              The nav menu will have two tabs - timetable and scores. For the icons on the nav buttons you can use the iconic icon set, same as the MAD9013 final. iconic-everything-1.9.0.zip

                              This page - https://algonquin.instructure.com/courses/501987/pages/handling-long-text-and-hyphens?module_item_id=9989609 should be helpful when dealing with lots of text in small spaces.

                               

                              Functional Requirements

                              When the app launches, it needs to fetch the data from the server and save it to localStorage. The next time you launch the app, it should check to see if the data is in localStorage and if the data is there then do NOT load new data.

                              The app should have some type of refresh button. If the user taps the refresh button then the data in localStorage needs to be replaced. You can use the "reload" icon from the iconic set if you want for this button.

                              Your will need to sort the data by dates to display the timetable of games. Numeric or Multi-dimensional Sorting

                              You will need to calculate the number of wins, losses, and ties and then sort the data by that information to display the scores.

                               

                              Submission

                              When you create your app, make sure that you name your app your username. You can edit your config.xml file to change it. On the phone we should see an app with your launcher icon plus your username. Eg: ABCD0001.

                              Also make sure that your package name includes your username so you are not overwriting anyone else's app.

                               

                              There are two parts to the submission.

                              1. Install your app on one of the Android Phones from the cabinet. Leave the name of the phone you used as a note here.

                              2. Upload your project to GitHub as a new Repo. Submit the URL of your Repo here. (This means your WHOLE CORDOVA folder)

                               

                              Challenge Feature

                              Often when working data we will want to "cache" that information. This means that we want to save the data locally but only for a specific amount of time. In this application that means that we would hang onto data stored in localStorage but for a limited time before we request a new copy.

                              When the deviceready / DOMContentLoaded event is triggered, we will need to check a timestamp saved in localStorage at the same time that the sport data was saved. This timestamp can be part of the sports data or a separate key. Compare this timestamp to the current time on the device. If the difference between the two times is more than one hour then we will make a new fetch( ) call to the server for a new copy of the data. Once the new data is received, we would replace the data in localStorage, set a new timestamp in localStorage, and then update the interface with the new data.

                                Video: How to add SplashScreens and icons to a Cordova Application

                                The video below demonstrates how to add SplashScreens and icons to your Cordova app. This includes modifying your config.sys file, storing your image content, installing a required plugin and copying the created image files to the platform folder:

                                 

                                Cordova SplashScreen and Icons (Links to an external site.)

                                Introduction to jQuery

                                A few years ago jQuery was the JavaScript library of choice for many developers, especially less experienced ones. Today jQuery is now a library that you will definitely come across and one that you should be aware of. However, it is not a library that is used by professional developers. It is a library used by designers who know only a little JavaScript.

                                It is a large libraries to add to your web sites and web apps especially now that JavaScript support is much more standardized across browsers and you can accomplish many of the same tasks with a minimal effort in plain JavaScript.

                                Often people add jQuery because they want access to one or two features in the library. However, you are stuck including the entire library just to use those one or two commands. 

                                So, the purpose of these lessons is:

                                1. Never add jQuery to your website or web app to solve a single problem that you can solve with vanilla JavaScript.

                                2. Be aware of how it works so you can edit sites that use it.

                                Here is the link to the site so you can download it and read the documentation: - https://jquery.com/ (Links to an external site.) 

                                DOM manipulation with jQuery

                                 

                                Working with Attributes - http://api.jquery.com/category/attributes/ (Links to an external site.)

                                CSS properties and Methods - http://api.jquery.com/category/css/ (Links to an external site.)

                                Traversing the DOM - http://api.jquery.com/category/traversing/ (Links to an external site.)

                                Working with the sizes of elements - http://api.jquery.com/category/dimensions/ (Links to an external site.) 

                                Manipulating the contents of the DOM - http://api.jquery.com/category/manipulation/ (Links to an external site.) 

                                Using Offsets for scrolling and dragging - http://api.jquery.com/category/offset/ (Links to an external site.)

                                Animations - http://api.jquery.com/category/effects/ (Links to an external site.)

                                CSS Selectors - http://api.jquery.com/category/selectors/ (Links to an external site.) (mostly the same as querySelector and querySelectorAll)

                                 

                                 

                                AJAX calls with jQuery

                                When using vanilla JavaScript we can use either:

                                let xhr = new XMLHttpRequest( );
                                xhr.open("GET", url, true);
                                xhr.addEventListener("load", function(ev){

                                });
                                xhr.addEventListener("error", function(err){

                                });
                                xhr.send(null);

                                OR

                                fetch(url)
                                .then(function(response){

                                }
                                .catch(function(err){

                                });

                                in order to make a request to a webserver / API for some data. When using jQuery, we can make an AJAX request with it's method calls. Here is the basic example equivalent for jQuery.

                                var xhr = $.ajax(url)
                                .done(function(){

                                })
                                .fail(function(){

                                });

                                For more details on all the properties: http://api.jquery.com/jQuery.ajax/ (Links to an external site.)

                                 

                                Further Study on jQuery

                                While not a recommended library any longer for someone who will become a JavaScript developer, it is something that you will definitely come across and there may be times when you want to use it for a proof of concept site or app.

                                To get more information try the two CodeSchool.com courses on Jquery

                                https://www.codeschool.com/courses/try-jquery (Links to an external site.)

                                and

                                https://www.codeschool.com/courses/jquery-the-return-flight (Links to an external site.)
